hear: Author blurbs in books & the Internet
explain1:
There are a few reasons it is primarily an American Award
1) Locals make up a large proportion of each Worldcon. Most Worldcons are held in the US, therefore a large proportion of the Voting group is always American
2) Up until the 21st Century voting was mostly in person (yes, paper ballot was possible but the majority of ballots were not paper). e-voting mean that non-attendees can vote easily now. And as most Worldcons were in the US, pre-21st Century voters were therefore mostly American
3) American fiction is known well in the rest of the world, but non-American literature is not known well in America. Therefore, the way the nomination system works, American works get on the ballot more often
hugosff: They reflect an aspect of SF&F - American non-YA SF&F
hugofandom: It reflects Worldcon fandom. It doesn't reflect Tumblr Fandom or Irish College Fandom or Library Reading Group Fandom or all the other subsets of "fandom" that exist.

hear: I don't know. I suspect that I have always had a vague awareness of them as long as I've been reading adult fiction from the age of about 12. The first two books which I knew had won the award were Neuromancer and American Gods.
explain1:
Yes, both historically and in the present. I do not have precise figures available to hand (it is late and I am tired), but I suspect more citizens of the United States of America (not the Americas) have won the Hugo Award than non-Americans, which would suggest to me that given the size of the USAs population in relation to the rest of the world in the last 75 years as an award for the World Science Fiction Convention is disproportionate. 

Also Worldcon is held more often in the United States with the nationality generally most represented being citizens of the USA. This drastically affects the nominations and voting. 

However, this is part of the award's character. Efforts to make it a genuinely world award are nice, but I suspect really for there to be an award that's representative and inclusive of all people then another serious award needs to be created which replaces the Hugo Award and has a less awful set of rules which bias the voting constituency against fiction that's not written both in the English language and published by publishing houses in the USA.
hugosff: Sort of. My sf/f is my sf/f and not going to be the same as your sf/f. hugofandom: See my answer above. I don't think it can or should be treated as the definitive view. The Hugo Award is like a photograph from the Hubble Space Telescope made from hundreds of different exposers using different lens which are then added together.

Their slate voting tactics are unpleasant and highlight how broken the Hugo Award is on an organizational level. However, I think that a counter-slate would be an equally distasteful effort and just perpetuate a very American culture war. 

They (the puppies) are can't stand that equality is a thing and a good one at that. 

So no, I don't think the puppies represent fandom as I see it, but they do represent their malignant festering tumorous part of fandom.

thoughts:
I would be interested in more regional identities being expressed in sf/f generally. At the moment we talk about being inclusive as involving bringing people into the conversation from different ethnicities and countries. As someone who is both from Europe and the United Kingdom, and has lived in other European countries and has cousins who are French, I am acutely aware that part of my identity is being erased when as a native English speaker my fiction and perspective is grouped with those perspectives from the United States of America, but also, sometimes, from the United Kingdom or England as a whole. And I really certain that we are all guilty of erasing people's identities when we say they are from Germany or America or China because someone who is from Berlin, New York, or Beijing does not share the same identity as someone who is from Munich, San Francisco or Hong Kong.

Personally, I am from the United Kingdom of Graham Joyce and Some Kind of Fairytale and not the United Kingdom of Charles Stross' Edinburgh. The societies we live in are the same nation with many similarities, but also lots of subtly differences which are what add character to our lives. 

It is utterly wrong to do this and we are harming ourselves by not diving into the interesting specifics. It's these differences which the puppies fear. It's the lack of a certain all encompassing identity which we must resist. I am like you, but I am also different from you in some ways, and that's awesome.

To be honest, I think the most engaging SFF stories I've come across in the last few years have all been in video games. Game writing should be more recognised in genre awards!

Does the voting population reflect the SF/F readership at large? No, probably not. Is that a problem? Not really, that readership has Goodreads and other such outlets. The Hugos are the expression of a particular community. That community grows and changes, and should continue to do so, and is often frustratingly slow about doing so, but I don't think it ever will or should be synonymous with "everyone who reads SF."

It's disgusting how they have behaved. It's a concerted effort to break the Hugos because they feel threatened by moves towards progress.

Modern fandom is a diverse, lively, and welcoming community which is about enjoying works with whole hearts. I don't recognise anything I would call 'fandom' in the toxic, exclusionary, aggressive attitudes of teh so-called 'puppies'.
categories: I find this a weird question. So I guess 'no'. I think growing up I cared more about the book categories because I was only aware of them. As a writer who has mostly only been elligible for nomination for 'Best Related Work', I'll admit to caring more about that in recent years, especially after a collection I was in was nominated for it, but I'm not sure I would say that makes me 'drawn' to the category. I'm interested in criticism, critique, and interpretation of the culture I enjoy, so that category is important to me. But so are the others. I have no idea if this at all relates to what you wanted. relevant:
I suppose the British Fantasy Society Awards. It's much easier for me to take part in them and they showed significant progressive tendencies last year. However, I have generally found most awards to be skewed towards the conservative. Recent changes, as we have seen, are open to fluctuation.

The Nebulas, also, seem more 'with the times' - more diverse and inclusive.

Probably more than anything else, the Kitschies reflect both the fun, the diversity, and the literary sensitivities that interest me.
thoughts:
I'm not sure that the main problem with the Hugos is georgaphical, which I take to be the main point of this survey. But there is a problem with encouraging an 'in crowd' to be considered, given how the Hugo votes are drawn, and the whole idea of a 'supporting membership' does not broaden this, but makes the Hugos particularly open to abuse by those with money and a bitter resentment of any but themselves enjoying fandom.

I've also seen more liberal people offering to buy supporting memberships for others to 'balance it out', but it seems to me this just underscores how fundamentally corrupt the whole Hugo voting model is. The rich vote. They will always tend to be older and more conservative.

explain1:
a) The Hugo Award is the award of Worldcon, which is de facto a primarily American convention; it would be silly to pretend anything else.

b) The Hugo Award is an award for works in English, and the US is the biggest English-speaking country. Of course it's not very relevant for e.g. Swedish literature -- very little Swedish fantasy or science fiction is ever translated into English. In the odd case when a Swedish writer write in English, for an American publication, with a primarily American audience in mind, that is, to me, not Swedish literature, but American literature that happens to be written by someone from Sweden. No international award could take into account works in only one language. The Hugo is for works in English, and that's fine. It will never be very relevant internationally. That's not really a problem.
hugosff:
The Hugo Awards have no ambition to reflect science fiction and fantasy as I see it. I read in several languages and the Hugo Awards are for works in English. There is absolutely no point to pretend to have a truly international award which takes only English works into account, and a sort of cultural colonialism to expect translations into English to be a priority for writers in other languages. 

With that said, and looking only at the world of English science fiction and fantasy, no, the Hugo Awards tend to skew towards populism. Be well liked, be known within fandom, and something you wrote will much easier be nominated. See Neil Gaiman, who will see his works nominated whether they deserve it or not, or John Scalzi, who will see his works nominated although they very rarely deserve it, which is probably at least partly due to the popularity of Whatever.
hugofandom: Of course not. It's an award given out by the members of Worldcon. It has never pretended to reflect the entire science fiction and fantasy fandom. If it did, the awards would probably be even more useless. This is not a bad thing. And yet again, it's an award of the English-speaking world. Of course it's dominated by people who speak English as their native language.
opinion: Some of them, sure. Pretty much everything I've written I've heard someone else say at least once.
sadpuppies:
No. They represent a fraction of (mainly) US fandom.

As does Worlcon members. But yet again, this is not "fandom's big award." It's an award given out by the members of Worldcon. Which is fine.
categories: The fan award categories are the only categories I can take seriously.
relevant: Yes, even if we keep to just the English-speaking world. Both the Tiptree Award and the Arthur C. Clarke Award both tend to award better literature. Probably because they're juried awards. Crowds are very bad at giving out awards to interesting works of fiction.
thoughts: It's a bit unclear whether you talk about English-speaking fandom, or international fandom. The potential answers to some of these questions would be vastly different depending on which alternative you mean.

thoughts: The Sad Puppy shit was an inevitable reaction to what's been going on in the awards. Winners who have written mediocre novels winning awards when astoundingly great works (some of which have been bestsellers) haven't even gotten on the ballot. What's most likely to happen is that the current crop of winners will fend off the puppy people. And for the next decade the award will keep being handed between the same few people with a rare breakout novel gaining attention if it shares the same political bent. There's a thing you can look up called "Group Polarization" which explains how groups end up (a) becoming more extreme and (b) becoming more homogenous in their philosophies. That's what happened to worldcon (and the Hugos) - it got stagnant and pleased with itself - the people doing really interesting and weird and exciting stuff (how the heck did Quantum Thief not end up on the ballot in its year, or Lexicon) - doesn't even show up on the radar for a cohort that is more interested in doddering about awarding the same writers for writing slight variations of the same novels that won awards in the past.

sadpuppies:
A giant mess. Sad Puppies has had some positives; it has convinced me that the Hugos are extremely ethically and sincerely run. It has also convinced me that far too small a number -- including this year the Puppies themselves -- are voting to nominate our field's most prestigious award. 

Neither represents fandom; each only a portion in my view. The average age of WorldCon attendees is getting older and older, and many of the choices (including those of the puppies) seem at best idiosyncratic.

It is also worth noting that the far more 'extreme' Rabid Puppies slate generally beat out the more moderate Sad Puppies slate. This does note bode well, at least for 2015 and certainly contributes to the feeling of a mess.

I was sad to see Marko Kloos withdraw (presumably under pressure), but delighted to see the 3-Body Problem appear. This tilts the Hugos slightly away from being 'all-American' and it is a very fine novel.

hear: Originally, probably from book covers. Then, from Locus and other fans.
explain1:
The 'World' in 'Worldcon' and 'World SF Society' is a misnomer. Or, rather, the meaning of that 'World' has shifted, and is still shifting, and is anyway viewed differently by different  people simultaneously. 

The first Worldcon was so named because it took place in New York, in 1939, and New York was simultaneously hosting the World's Fair. There was, so far as I know, no association between the two.

I presume though there was some notion of bringing the world of science fiction to New York's sf fans, and this developed into a convention that moved around the US, providing people with a chance to meet authors and one another. It seems like a very innocent endeavour, and I can imagine for them the world was North America and its developing fan groups, with some activity in the UK and no real idea what went on elsewhere. While they were doubtless shaped in part by an infant ideology of if it doesn't happen here, it doesn't happen anywhere else, they weren't really in a position to test that theory.(At some point someone needs to do a serious study of the effects of World War II on fan attitudes – not a history of who was where when but a proper sociohistorical study with grown-up theory in it.)

So,initially, 'world' does not mean world. At least, not like that. There are occasional forays beyond the North American continent (London, Heidelberg, Melbourne) but there's a sense that this is a treat for overseas fans, taking the show abroad once in a while. By the time I came along, there was a complex bid-zoning system for where in the US the convention could go by rotation, and when overseas bids could be submitted, and NASFICs for the years when the convention left North America (much of the zoning stuff seems to have died a death, presumably thanks to cheaper flights across the US). So it's clearly been positioned as a North American convention that goes abroad occasionally, not as a 'world', that is global, convention.

It is only comparatively recently that the emphasis on 'world' as 'global' has arisen, which I attribute to the many, many changes in the way the sf community perceives itself, its ability to keep in touch with people, different attitudes towards sf, all the stuff that's been rehearsed a hundred times across blogs and social media. And I think this is a very good thing. 

But only this week I've talked to people who thought that 'world' always meant 'global' and hadn't realised how the convention was originally named, which has clarified my puzzlement about their puzzlement.

What does this have to do with the Hugos?

The Hugos began as a one-off award given by one Worldcon. The following year's Worldcon didn't give them, but then Worldcons started to do it regularly and the association between the two became a legal one.To be a Worldcon, one of the things a convention must do is to agree to host and administer the Hugos. They were originally called Annual Science Fiction Achievement Awards until they officially became the Hugos. I suppose we might argue that they honoured the world of sf insofar as the voters understood it, which was a world in which sf was published in the US by mostly white men and some women. In other words, like most awards, they honoured the community  which gave them, and this supposed that there was one community. (I doubt there ever really was but like all dysfunctional communities they pull together for the year's big celebration.)

Worldcons have got bigger, as more people read sf and fantasy, and more people read a broader range of sf and fantasy, and critically, more people outside the Anglo-American axis read and write sf, but because the convention has been primarily tied to North America, I'm not sure these huge shifts in demographic have necessarily been reflected as immediately in Hugo nominating/voting patterns as it ought to have been. Indeed, it's been notoriously difficult to get an English novel or piece of non-fiction that isn't a zine onto a ballot. 

In part that would be because North Americans couldn't get hold of the UK material easily (whatever we might feel about Amazon et al it's amazingly easy to get a text these days) but equally, because it was incredibly difficult and expensive to send money abroad. International money orders were very expensive, very few UK people had US checking accounts, and credit cards had barely been invented, and weren't available to many ordinary people in the UK. I'm sure this is part of the reason why there has traditionally been a UK book blip in nominating patterns the year after a UK worldcon, because people had the power to nominate, and had been able to buy a voting membership too without having to deal with currency exchange (though Worldcons did, of course, eventually begin to have some foreign agents to deal with that – it would be interesting to see what the take-up was for that before the internet made everything easier). 

But even now, there have been recent years when I was just too broke to afford £25 to buy a supporting membership to vote (or maybe I didn't care enough to starve – who knows :-) ) And I'm probably not the only one. 

And in that the Hugo Awards reside within the Worldcon, which is still primarily a convention for North American fans, yes, I think it is primarily an American award. I'm not sure it intends to be, but if the award administration resides within a convention that is primarily a US convention, and is, or has been, primarily voted on by USians, with no mechanism for outreach, how can it be anything but primarily an American award? And to describe itself now as a 'world' award seems more risible than it did forty or fifty years ago, when it pretty much was.
hugosff: Not really. Sometimes it does, sometimes it doesn't. Popular votes are about popular books. Popular doesn't necessarily mean well-written  but it does mean that people like the book or its author, or both. I don't like a lot of popular sf or fantasy because it's literally generic, often badly written, and is just not my thing. It's frustrating but I live with it, and I don't feel any particular desire to tear down the fabric of society because I can't get my own way. But sometimes we all agree, and that's nice.
hugofandom:
That is a tricky question because Hugo Award voters may or may not be a sub-set of Worldcon members, and they may or may not be actual Worldcon attendees, and that's a whole different subset of people. And what is fandom anyway? 

There are some people who would argue that because I rarely go to Worldcon I am not a fan, not a proper fan. Indeed, because I rarely go to conventions now, I'm not a proper fan. Others would argue that because I don't produce a fanzine, about fans, I'm not a proper fan. (Though when I did, I still wasn't a proper fan; see reasons above.)  For sure, there have been people who think that because I write about books in a more academic way, I'm not a proper fan. And if those are the criteria, I'm fairly sure I'm not a proper fan, and happy not to be so.

But if by fan we mean people who love sf and fantasy in their diverse forms, talk about it, etc, in public, then yes, I'm a fan, though my participation in 'fandom' is mainly in social media and literary arenas.

But it's almost impossible to know who Hugo voters are, except through what they nominate and vote on. I think it would be fair to say that most Hugo *voters* rarely share my taste in sf and fantasy but a fair number of *nominators* might share some of my tastes. And I have many good friends with appalling taste in books.
opinion: Define 'area'? Geographically, I have no idea as I don't have much contact with fans face-to-face on a regular basis. The places where I participate online? I think a fair number would share my opinion, but I can't speak for the lurkers.
sadpuppies:
They don't represent the fans I know best, but those I know best tend to be progressives rather than conservatives, so there is that to start with.

Then we need to separate Sad Puppies from the Rabid Puppies. 

The Sad Puppies seem to me to represent a group of mainly men who hanker after the lost golden age of twelve in a Ray Bradbury novel, when they were the centres of their own personal universes, and sex, work, and people not adoring their awesomeness was not an issue. They seem to be drawn to every marker of masculinity you can think of so I imagine the modern world must come as something of a shock to them. Particularly the bits about being called out for the way they refer to women, homosexuals, other ethnicities, and pretty much anyone who isn't a white cishet gun-toting man's man like them. 

(Excuse my sarscasm. Actually, don't.)

But there are Sad Puppies and Sad Puppies, i.e the people who the Sad  Puppies have determined share their values because their fiction implies they might do.  So, on top of all their other crimes, there is a failure to distinguish fiction from real life,and to separate author from text.

More seriously, I think the actual Sad Puppies seem to be symptomatic of a broader social movement of men who have discovered that the world doesn't revolve round them and are not very good at figuring out why this might be and how best to deal with it,and can't shut up about how much it hurts. They're all 'I could have been a contender', or that difficult uncle who turns up at Christmas to whine about not having had the breaks, and haven't noticed that if they cleaned up their acts, they still could be contenders, though I still wouldn't vote for the kind of stuff they write because it's dull and old-fashioned. But lots of people do like what they write; they just liked what someone else wrote better when Correia didn't win the Campbell. This is the big problem. They're dealing in absolutes (because they're twelve) rather than in gradations, like grown-ups. 

The Rabid Puppies – and here I mean Theodore Beale and, yes, John C Wright, because I regard him as much more dangerous than the likes of Correia and Torgerson – are a whole different thing. Beale is utterly detestable but much more politically savvy than the likes of LC and BT (as witnessed by their getting him involved in the first place). And much the same could be said of JCW.

The Sad Puppies sort of emerge from a line of jolly fannish japes, like buying a voting membership for your pet rock, even though they were hamfisted in trying to turn the Hugos back to real fiction by real men (i.e.the stuff they write) but the RPs seem to me to be simply using the Hugos as but one more arena for a much more fundamental disagreement with society about their position, or lack of position, in it. It is really all about white male supremacy, and the Hugos just turn out to be collateral damage this year, and probably in years to come.

In many respects, the biggest problem the sf community has got is that it is trying to Save the Hugos when it could be using its considerable energy to campaign about things like black teenagers getting shot, the erosion of women's reproductive rights, diversity issues, combatting the MRA movement, and using sf texts to illustrate their arguments rather than trying to preserve the non-existent sanctity of an award because  … tradition. 

This is not to say that many fine people do not devote time to these issues as well as trying to Save the Hugos, but the Hugos are not going to be saved like that. They've lost their innocence, insofar as they ever had any (which is of course the point the SPs were in their cackhanded fashion making, and they were up to a point correct) so better to think about what to do in future, bearing in mind the ridiculous restrictions round trying to make any changes, and stop fretting about reclothing the Hugos in virginal white. 

Having said that, the Save the Hugos faction does indeed represent the kind of fandom I know. Very well-meaning, sometimes almost child-like in its desire to do the right thing, heavily vested in its history and traditions, basically good-hearted but sometimes very unworldly. And unfortunately, the world has come to them.

I can't imagine that we'll ever be able to go back to the happy, prelapsarian world where people good-naturedly campaigned for their mates and David Gerrold could win a Hugo for a frankly execrable story because it was all about his adopted son and … ah!!!

In a way, I'm not sure I want to. On the other hand, I can see that for many people it's a hell of a shock to move from that to something akin to neo-Nazis demanding you vote for a slate that has been carefully selected for its literary purity, with nothing in between. 

I doubt I am the only British observer who seems a certain similarity between the SPs and UKIP and the RPs and the British National Party and the English Democratic League and all the other far-right splinter groups we have.
categories:
Yes. I am always more interested in the text-based categories, fiction and, sometimes best related. I'm more interested recently in fanzine/fan writer because of the way it's shifted from the same old names churning out the same old fan history in paper zines to people writing online about fandom now (though having said that I shall happily nominate Mike Glyer for fan writer for his exemplary journalism on the Sad Puppies case, because he has truly done good work that deserves to be recognised). 

I would like to see the fiction categories streamlined, to something like long and short form, but can't imagine I will live long enough given the speed at which the process moves. 

I'd still like to see something address critical writing, review, commentary more effectively than brw/best fan writer tries to, but I know I have a vested interest, and I also know it would also just make the whole thing far more complicated than it already is. (Having said that, I also know that there is a peculiar little gap between popular and peer-reviewed academic that isn't fully addressed except by the Atheling award, and that's only for Australians.)

thoughts:
There are too many things wrong with the Hugos to list here (and that's before we got to the Puppies controversy). Two of the main problems are: 1) that it is presented as a World SF award when it isn't even representative of English Language sf (how many books published in Australia have made a Hugo ballot, for example).
2) That it is governed in a way that makes more problems than it solves. A pretence of democracy is simply a disguise for bureaucracy. Any change to the rules tends to make things more complex not less, and the organisation is such that it simply cannot react quickly to any situation. The earliest that any response to the Puppies can come into effect is two years down the line (and is likely to make the awards more complex not more effective), by which time the Puppies are likely to have either destroyed the award or changed their attack so that the response is irrelevant.

These people do not represent fandom as I see and experience it, but maybe I experience a certain brand of leftie permissive fandom...

I think the SP/RP slate has betrayed the sense of fair play that previously permeated the process. It was "Not the done thing" to form a slate (apparently it's only recently become acceptable to provide a list of your own works so people know what they can nominate you for). In the future Slates and opposing slates will probably become the norm unless you can change the rules to restrict them.

having a random idea wherein national science fiction conventions get a small block of nominations/votes which can be submitted to the hugos.

These could be voted on by the membership of that national convention (e.g. eastercon in the UK) and allow those who attend that convention but not worldcon to have some input into the hugos.

Probably a complete pain in the ass to implement and in many ways possibly worse than the current system, but might help make things a bit more global.

hear: I first heard about them on the covers of novels which said "Hugo award winning author", I think.
hugosff:
Many of the Hugo Award categories are for types of work (or people) that I really know nothing about, and am not that interested in. 

Of the categories that do mean something to me, the nominations for Dramatic Presentation (Long & Short) and Graphic Story do seem relevant. Best Related Work sometimes seems to include very arcane items (e.g. albums of sf folk music) but is mostly fine by me. 

The Best Novel nominations often strike me as a bit odd, not because the works nominated are insufficiently popular with a mass audience but because their presence on the ballot frequently seems to have more to do with the enthusiasms and loyalties of the various factions within Worldcon fandom than with what I would regard as literary quality. There's generally at least one or two books on the ballot which I'd say were "Hugo worthy", though - I'm just not convinced that they really represent a sampling of the "best of the field".
hugofandom:
No.

Sf and fantasy fandom is a very broad church these days, made up of many sub factions, and people who regularly go to Worldcon strike me as their own subgroup which is not particularly representative of "sf and fantasy enthusiasts" as a whole.
opinion:
I think most sf fans I know, and most people within the UK who are sf and fantasy enthusiasts, would share a lot of the opinions I've expressed here.

People who regularly go to Eastercon and other "traditional sf cons" in the UK are probably more in tune with the Hugos, more likely to have at least heard of the nominees in categories like Best Fancast or Best Editor, and so on.
sadpuppies:
Neither side represents fandom as I see it.

I believe that the Hugos, while always political, have become increasingly factionalised recently. This might be to do with the internet, which makes it easier for people to become aligned with a group and only read or nominate works on the recommended reading lists of their own faction. Slate voting, however, represents another escalation of factionalism, and I disapprove of it on principle.
categories:
To be honest, most of the categories strike me as more important to "traditional sf convention fandom" than to me, or to most people interested in science fiction and fantasy. Which is entirely reasonable, given that the Hugos are awarded by Worldcon members, but does mean that I'm really not that concerned about most of the categories.

So what do I care about? Best Novel, Best Dramatic Presentation (Long & Short Forms), Best Graphic Story and Best Related Work. 

In theory I should also be interested in the best short story / novella / novelette categories, but in practice I don't read new short fiction apart from the occasional single author collection, and neither does anyone else I see regularly, so these awards are pretty much irrelevant to me.
relevant:
The Clarke Award, which is chosen by a jury who have actually read most of the works which might theoretically be eligible in a given year and is thus less prone to factional voting and identity politics.

The Kitschies, which seem much more open to new forms (meaning the "Invisible Tentacle" for natively digital fiction).
thoughts:
Personally, I feel that the lack of a Hugo Award for "best game" makes the Hugos look very out of touch with sf and fantasy as a whole. Imagine that in 1980 there were no awards for Best Dramatic Presentation because most Worldcon fans didn't watch films or own a TV. That's pretty much how I feel about the lack of a games award :)

(I suspect that many Hugo voters feel that games are inherently inferior to other forms in some way, but the idea that something like Mass Effect is fundamentally less worthwhile as a work of sf than, say, Babylon 5 - which won two Hugos - strikes me as very strange.)

opinion: Yes
sadpuppies: It has caused irreparable damage to the reputation and good names of the Hugo and of SFF fandom, which is almost entirely the fault of established fan-run management of the community. In less than a decade, the Hugo has gone from a calling card to Hollywood for SFF creators, to a flame war with white supremacists and Tea Party goons. You could see - from space, ironically - that this was going to happen and yet the mostly white and mostly American SFF fandom sat on its hands and hoped the problem would go away. Just as American fandom sat on its hands and hoped Marion Zimmer Bradley's child abuse wasn't real (her photo was still up at the London world con as a "professional SF writer). Yes, the puppies represent traditional SFF fandom just as Fox News playing in a MacDonald's in Indiana represents the American midwest. Most people stopping by a MacDonalds probabaly don't agree with Bill O'Reilly but they do nothing to stop his toxic opinions from spreading in public space.

thoughts: Vox Day and his fellow travellers have made specific threats of violence and death against specific people (women writers and African American writers). There is no other global community of fans or other similar professional industry I can think of which would tolerate overtly criminal behaviour of political extremists and racists. The failure to take any decisive action to enforce community standards or involve law enforcement in what is - clearly - an organised criminal network engaged in harassment has invited Day and his supporters to hijack part of SFF fandom. I think it unlikely the Hugo award can ever recover from the current reputational crisis it's brought on itself through lethargy and complacency.

thoughts:
Of the suggested solutions to the Puppy problem, the one I like best is this:
1: The first work to be shortlisted in a category is the one with most nominations.
2: The second work is the one with most nomitations, disregarding ballots that include the first shortlisted work.
3: Repeat until 5 works have been shortlisted.
This way, each ballot can only get one work on the shortlist, vastly reducing the problem with slates.

I think there are various things which people enjoy about SF:
 - Adventures in space, competent heroes, positive and rational visions of the future (some MilSF, some of Heinlein's works)
- Explorations of the effects of future tech, politics or events on people (eg. dystopias, 'literary SF')
- The novum: new ideas, interesting puzzles, new science, predictions.
All of these are good and interesting to me. Seems like SP value the first mostly and object to the second. It's hard to know exactly what the SP crowd really value because they are unclear whether they're nominating repulican works in order to anger democrats, or whether they're actually voting for stuff they really like. The entire Sad Puppies issue basically stems from them not seeing the kind of books they like nominated (that and Theodore Beale being a truly toxic person). I have some sympathy with the idea that the Hugo should reflect all elements of the genre and that includes the popular, the commercial and the adventure story, but I disagree utterly with their claims of a liberal / SJW conspiracy as there's no basis in fact there, and their methods for derailing the voting were destructive not creative / constructive. 

It comes down to whether you can hold two ideas in your head at once - being interested by the shortlists as an alternative perspective on a genre you love without feeling that your own taste is being questions. Awards don't sneak into people's houses and swap out your favourite books for ones on their lists!

The Hugo Award should not change it's voting system simply in the light of the Sad Puppies campaigning. This is a blip and the brand hasn't been tarnished long term, it might even benefit. 

This isn't to say that changes might be good to consider as part of a broader agenda, but not one that simply seeks to prevent a fresh Puppy slate. 

Reading between the lines you kind of get the sense that except for Beale the other puppies are kind of trying to hide from the fallout now.

I'm very disappointed with it, especially with the use of a slate. Encouraging people to nominate works is a great idea, suggesting works that are eligible for nomination is acceptable providing there's a large enough number of suggestions, but providing a slate to nominate is abhorrent.

I think the SP proponents certainly represent a portion of fandom - the majority probably represent a perfectly respectable portion of fandom, though not one I'd necessarily agree with in many areas. The RP proponents, on the other hand, seem to either have nothing whatsoever to do with fandom, or represent a very small niche area which most of fandom would prefer to avoid.
categories:
There are categories I feel more strongly about and ones I feel I know more about, yes.

I generally read novel-length stories in preference to shorter ones, so the novella/novellette/short story categories are ones I'm less familiar with. Having said that, those that make it to the Hugo nominations are generally very enjoyable/thought provoking.

The editorial categories (long-form especially) are ones I don't feel in any way qualified to judge. While I have some awareness of what an editor does, I don't see any way to judge that from just the finished work (okay, with short story collections you can make some judgement based on the selection, but that's it really), other than by those which fail badly (which should never make it to nomination anyway).

If I do buy a supporting membership and vote - and I am seriously considering it - 'No Award' is going to figure prominently - but we can get over this.

hear: You read enough English-language SFF and you hear about it by osmosis. Amusingly, I used to think the Hugos were genuinely a signifier of quality. I no longer do.
explain1:
Most voters are Americans, most nominees likewise. The path to ballots is done via networking (cons, SFWA membership, Codex voting blocs, workshop voting blocs, Writers of the Future scientology connections), which primarily privileges Americans by virtue of geography. For non-westerners, the costs of attending cons or networking-oriented workshops are financially deleterious.

Some non-Americans are successful. Here's why: Aliette de Bodard frequently attends cons in the UK and the US, is on the Codex forums, has attended Orson Scott Card's writing workshop, and IIRC won Writers of the Future.
hugosff: No. They reflect popularity contests, networking, social capital and privilege. Mediocre-to-bad writers can claw their ways up the ballots as long as they schmooze well enough. There are voting blocs within the Codex writing forums, the SFWA itself, etc. All sections of fandom are mobs waiting to be weaponized, whether they happen to be led by Vox Day or an 'acceptable' liberal.
opinion: Nobody in my area knows what a Hugo is. Not in Hong Kong, not in Thailand. Sorry. I expect mainland Chinese SFF scene knows of it, though. Probably the Japanese neither know nor care.
sadpuppies: I'm apathetic. SFF comprises primarily of crypto-bigots masquerading as liberal allies and out-and-out bigots. Whichever set wins, bigots will still dominate the field and nothing will change. The Nielsen Haydens and Kathryn Cramer are still respected despite having been psychopathic harassers during Racefail '09 (not to mention that Cramer's gotten drunk and assaulted panelists in public at a con). Similarly, Harlan Ellison continues to be respected despite having groped Connie Willis onstage. John C. Wright is not going to lose his publishing contracts with Tor any time soon.
categories: Not really.
relevant: Not really. The Locus Awards are political in a different way (essentially juried by Locus staff and affected by their politics/vendettas/whatever current dramas), the Tiptree is juried by Americans, the Clarke/Kitschies juried by Britons. Some years have higher-quality shortlists than others. I don't believe award nomination to be a mark of quality. When works of quality win or get nominated, it's a matter of networking skills more than the work's quality itself.

sadpuppies: It is appalling. They have subverted SFF fandom to promote their own right wing, sexist, racist political agenda. SFF should be a mind-expanding genre where all kinds of ideas are explored. The puppies thing has hijacked fandom for their own ends and made a complete farce of the Hugos. Frankly I think the instigators should be publicly castigated for their offensive behaviour and total lack of respect for anyone who does not agree with their narrow-minded, bigoted prejudices. They do not represent me, nor any of the many SFF fans I know personally.
categories: I have more interest in the Best Novel, Best Novella, Best Short Story and Best Non-Fiction awards than in the art and TV/film awards. Just personal preference as I tend to read a lot.
relevant: The Arthur C Clarke Award is most relevant, mainly because the long list books are nominated by their publishers, then read by a panel, cut down to a short list, which is then voted on by that same panel to find the winner. The panel is made up of writers and fans. Every stage is clearly set out and the panel members are publicised. I know people who have been part of the process and there is no input from anyone outside the panel when deciding on the award winner. Maybe the Hugos could learn from this, given the current debacle.
thoughts: Sadly the Hugos have fallen victim to the sad state of US politics, where white straight men believe their (very restricted) worldview is the only one worth considering. The puppies have elevated US-centric, right wing, militaristic, fundamentalist Christian politics to a position it does not merit, at the expense of anyone who does not agree with them. That is facism. The Nazis couldn't have dreamt up better. It is shameful and embarrassing to those of us who love SFF and welcome diversity in all its forms in our choice of reading material. Their hatred of women, POC, LGBT, for example, diminishes the Hugo awards and SFF fandom in general and frankly, it is offensive in the extreme. Sadly, the whole puppies scenario is a reflection of US society and the direction the political situation there is heading. I will not comply with their bully-boy tactics and sincerely wish the people in charge of the Hugos take note and enact measures to ensure this never happens again.

hear: Discussion in secondhand Asimov's and Analog magazine copies and the introductions in Larry Niven's "N-Space."
explain1: The vast, vast majority of fiction winners have been American, and the handful who were British and Canadian are in the single digits. As far as I know, no non-Anglophone writer has ever won, and very few have been nominated. The Dramatic Presentation goes almost inevitably to Hollywood film and TV productions (with the exception of Doctor Who). The graphic novels also seem to be mostly American publications.
hugosff:
No. There is a lot of Russian sf I am aware of that doesn't get translated and if it does, doesn't get nominated. So I assume that the situation is very similar for French, Chinese, Polish, Finnish, Indian SF, etc. Not even considering the language barrier, Australia and New Zealand publish a fair amount of quality SF and have never had a representative author nominated for Best Novel. Even the UK has a huge SF scene (Christopher Priest, Alastair Reynolds, Nick Harkaway and many others) which doesn't even get nominations. 

Also, the works that do get nominated tend to appeal to US politics and show US concerns --- a US view of racism and colonialism with not that much regard to class, a US view of the military, of capitalism and of health care.
hugofandom: No. I have been to a WorldCon (Chicon 7 in 2012) and found that the attendees there, who are presumably mostly Hugo voters, are not as diverse as they try to be. The vast majority are American, with the remainder mostly Canadian (as trans-atlantic crossings for a convention are unfeasible for the UK and European scene, not to speak of the African, Asian and Australian fans). Also, the majority seem to be 40+ years old, middle class, and employed in white-collar jobs. (I am not going to speak of the racial breakdown as others have discussed it better than me and it appeals to a US definition of race.)
opinion: A lot of Canadian fans who attend conventions follow the Hugos. However, a lot of the people I know enjoy Lord of the Rings and Game of Thrones and YA fantasy and SF --- without it ever occurring to them to go to a convention or vote for the Hugos, or even that the Hugos are anything that matters. Some Canadian friends of mine pointedly ignore the Hugos as an American popularity contest.
sadpuppies: It is a problem of American politics on both sides, polarized over American issues of race and homophobia and an American idea of religion (Evangelicalism and Mormonism). The response to the Sad Puppies, though it aligns slightly better with my values, does not represent me either, as it is entirely focused on American political issues of anti-racism and anti-homophobia, in a situation that is very different even from Canada's.
categories: I am interested in the fiction categories. I don't really care about the Graphic Novel or Dramatic Presentation categories (even the filmmakers themselves don't care that they got a Hugo for best Dramatic Presentation, why would they?). I don't read fanzines and I find that the Best Related Work is a matter of what gets the most links rather than what is actually a best non-fiction work. I find it very difficult to judge who gets Best Editor, as the point of a good editor is that his or her work should be invisible.
relevant: I recently have found the Kitschies very interesting in suggesting different and original novels in their nominees. I would read the World Fantasy Award winners, especially their short fiction. The Clarke Award can also recommend good novels. There are far fewer good awards for short fiction than for long.
thoughts: I hope the results of this survey see some eyeballs, but I am skeptical at how much the Hugo Awards/WorldCon can change, both from the American fan base being reluctant to move it, and the non-American fan base not caring about it.

hear: Blurbs on book covers
hugosff: No
hugofandom: Probably, but I dislike fandom. I was an SF reader for more than a dozen years before I heard of fandom, and then once I exposed to it I was appalled by how profoundly unappealing it all was.
opinion: Yes, and we often talk about how fandom has become increasingly insular and unpleasant at the same time that SF itself has seduced and conquered the world.
sadpuppies: I think both sides are wrong-headed; it's like seeing two groups of cry-baby idiots fighting; everybody comes off looking bad,but it's an entertaining show to watch from the sidelines. That said, although I had never heard of him before this whole controversy, Larry Correia's posts have been unfailingly thoughtful and level-headed, while most of fandom's posts have been whiny and self-entitled. I disagree entirely with Correia's politics and esthetics, but he has legitimate gripes and makes convincing arguments about some of what's broken in fandom.
categories: I don't care at all about any of the categories save for the four principal fiction categories, and to some extent also the "related work" category. I would care about some of the editor and zine awards, but their divisions and categorizations are so fraught with controversy that they're tainted. I especially do not care about all the "fan" categories. Even the four major fiction awards, I've long ago stopped paying close attention to, so rare is it that anything truly award-worthy gets any attention. The whole fandom popularity contest aspect of it all is very off-putting.
relevant: In theory, juried awards are more likely to be relevant, but fandom culture often infects those, too, as fandom-types become professionals (and jurors) whose esthetics skew toward fandom appeal rather than quality.
thoughts: At this point, the best thing that could happen to SF would be for fandom to implode and disappear and stop embarrassing everyone. Or, at least, for fandom to fully disassociate itself from SF and finally embrace that it no longer has anything at all to do with SF. Let it become a social club of some sort, but it should stop claiming SF as its own.

X:
The entire SP/RP debacle is insulting to everyone who voted for the first time at Loncon3 like I did - we produced a list of nominations that reflected our cultural background, our attendance at a Worldcon. Europeans/Britons don't think the same way as right-wing Americans, by and large, and the SP/RP need to just accept that. No one rigged 2014. It was a true representation of a section of fandom that they were merely unfamiliar with. 2015 is a not-entirely-true representation of a very tiny section of fandom that I do not recognise as 'my people' at all. 

Also: fair play to those who have withdrawn rather than be associated with such a discredited process.

hear: Probably about 1986/7. I was at the Worldcon in 1987 and went to the Hugo presentation. I probably knew about the awards before then.
explain1: I answered 'no' but I think I would probably have answered 'yes' 10 years ago. Maybe even five years ago. I don't doubt that the Hugo voter packet has changed the demographic.
hugosff: Probably, roughly. In that, aside from this year, most categories usually have one or two good choices and one or two that I think are pretty questionable. I guess typically maybe a third of the awards where I have an opinion go to the thing I voted in top place.
hugofandom: Probably, roughly, although less so than the previous answer. I suspect a lot of my British fan friends don't regularly participate, and many older friends have given up on the Hugos entirely.Which I entirely accept. I only have a problem with people whining that it was better in 1968 and so we should pretend that it is indeed 1968.
opinion: As noted, I think a lot of my British fan friends care less about participating than I do. I think, though, that Recent Events may have increased interest. I was at the British Eastercon for the announcement and a subsequent scratch panel to discuss what happened and the room was full. I didn't hear anybody at that panel or elsewhere expressing any support or sympathy for the SP/RP position. That may be a reflection of my friends -- who I imagine are all left/liberal -- and it may be that anybody who was SP/RP sympathetic wasn't inclined to speak up against the majority, but my general sense is that there's no support for the SP/RP movement in active British fandom, or at least that bit of it that I encounter.
sadpuppies: I'm drawn to Martin Lewis's analysis, that we need to look at Hugo recommendations/slates against scales of Authority, Direction and Self-interest. As such I think both SP and RP and all slate-based activities are contrary to the spirit of the rules. I'm not a fan of the trend for self-promotion in the last decade or so -- probably because I'm British -- but I've not seen anything remotely comparable before and I think any suggestion that this is a response to some shady cabal that's been controlling the awards is nonsense.
categories: Historically, the fan categories (disclosure: I'm a former nominee). Less so now, because of the way they've evolved -- although that's not to say that I disagree with the way they've evolved. Honestly, I think it was probably for the best, and they rarely reflected my view of what was good anyway. I do quite like the short fiction categories, because I don't read much of that these days and so the Hugos are a filter to give me a recommended reading list, from which I can usually bank on at least one or two really good pieces per category. I'm not really interested in the BDP categories. I've argued for years in favour of ditching all the categories we have now and rebuilding the Hugos from scratch for the 21st century, but I accept that it's probably not practical.
relevant: The Arthur C Clarke Award, which I've followed from the start, has generated what are to me consistently better shortlists than the Hugo. The Tiptree and the Kitschies are looking interesting. I do watch most major awards shortlists to a degree.
thoughts:
I'm entirely happy with the idea that the Hugos are the awards given out by the WSFS which is to say the Worldcon. I don't feel the need to make them more inclusive by hugely increasing the voter base, although I certainly don't object to more people wanting to participate in the Worldcon within the constraints of its fundamental nature. I hope this fuss doesn't destroy the Hugos but I don't think I'd be wildly upset if it did.

Thanks for taking the time to put this together. I'll be interested to see what you do with it all.

explain1: Well, the Worldcon is a world convention in name only. Some fans travel for it every year, yes. But the majority of the membership is North American, and the Hugos reflect the tastes of the majority of Worldcon members.

explain1: For a number of historical and contemporary reasons, U.S. residents have dominated Worldcon in terms of hosting and Hugo voting. This isn't the result of an evil conspiracy; it's a result of the population size of the U.S. as compared to most other countries. Both of these have been becoming more diverse in the last couple of decades (5 of the last 10 Worldcons were outside U.S.; the Hugo ballot the last 15 years has averaged only about 50% U.S. nominees), BUT more gender and nationality diversity is still needed.

I think they way they have chosen to try and achieve their goals (while legal) is childish, dishonest, and against everything the Hugos have been for many years (which is a wide range of people doing their best to honestly nominate and vote).

hear: Longtime SFF fan, and the child of two SFF readers. Books with "Hugo Award Winner" and "Nebula Award Winner" blazoned on the cover were a key part of my reading as a teen. Frankly, there must have been a time when I had not heard of the Hugo Awards, but I cannot remember it.
explain1: I think it primarily reflects the current North American market and con-going fandom. While writers from other countries are sometimes nominated for the Hugos, it is only when their works are published by a North American publisher that they come to the attention of Hugo voters.
hugosff:
Not particularly. But then, I also think it's ridiculous to think that it could reflect all of SFF, or that it should.

I do feel that, historically, good works make it on the ballot. I don't always agree with the Hugo voting base, and sometimes lament the absence of a favored work, or raise an incredulous eyebrow at something that did make the ballot. Given that it's an award chosen by popular vote rather than a jury (i.e. representative of a broader range of tastes), this is not surprising.
hugofandom:
I think Hugo Award voters reflect the opinions of the people who attend Worldcon and/or who care enough about the awards themselves to pay to vote. Nothing more, nothing less.

"Fandom" is not one thing anymore, and as a term I'd argue that it's no longer only applicable to people who attend science fiction conventions. There are many ways to interact with other fans, authors, artists, etc., without ever once attending (or wanting to attend) a traditional SF convention. Frankly, this is a good thing, and I welcome the fresh fans and voices that come to the genre from anime, movies, TV, comics, and more.

However, it is very true to say that while the Hugo Award voters may be more representative of a particular slice of SFF fandom, their tastes are perhaps not representative of the wider science fiction and fantasy readership. I know many people who are big readers and primarily read SFF works but have no interest in SFF fandom, nor nominating/voting for awards. This does not mean that there is a flaw in the system; this is not representative of a conspiracy. Frankly, I think that SFF readership and fandom are becoming too large and diverse to be fully represented in a single award or slate of nominees--and I see this as a good thing.
opinion: Yes, I'd wager that many in my immediate circle would hold similar opinions. You'd certainly find a diversity of opinions if you were to survey all of Canadian fandom; however, at a recent convention I overheard and participated in a number of conversations relating to the recent SP/RP controversy, and found little support for either.
sadpuppies:
Ridiculous, frustrating, and an excellent example of the increasingly polarized "us vs. them," "left vs. right" mindset one sees reflected so clearly in American politics.

I do not support SP or RP, and while I can understand the feelings of hurt/exclusion (etc.) expressed by some of the SP, I do not feel that their actions are correct or justified. I condemn RP wholeheartedly. Nor do I feel that their actions are representative of some great "silent majority" of SFF fans.

There is no one fandom! There is no right way or correct opinion. While SP/RP demonstrably represent a component of fandom, I do not see them as representing, speaking for, or championing fandom as a whole.
categories:
The novel category is really a standout. As I don't read a lot of short fiction, the three short (or shorter) fiction categories are generally of less interest. Categories like "Best Editor" and "Best Artist" rarely seem to reflect the work done in a particular year and often just seem like a general popularity contest (though I certainly think that artists, editors, fan writers, etc., deserve to be recognized for their work).

Rather than so much focus on short SF (which, I'd argue, used to be more important to the genre than it is today), I'd love to see a few novel categories -- perhaps Best SF, Best Fantasy, etc. Maybe even recognition for the great work being done for writers of YA SFF.
relevant: I find a number of awards interesting, but have no one "go to" award in terms of something that will always match my taste or opinions.
thoughts: Unlike SP/RP, I was quite happy to see the increasing diversity of authors and works represented on recent Hugo ballots, and quite enjoy some more "literary" SFF works.

explain1:
As shown in a recent analysis by Aidan Walsh of Hugo winners, only 19% of winners for best novel have been non-American. 

This situation - which had shown some improvement over the past 10 years (much like the increase in the number of women nominees) - is now beholden to the Sad/Rapid Puppies controversy. I expand on this below, but the Sad Puppies (and the reaction against it) is largely about right-wing Americans trying to claim supreme victim status over left-wing Americans (who also love to claim victim status). 

It narrows the debate to the thinnest of slivers. It reduce the award back to almost solely a US concern.
hugosff: Not really.
hugofandom: Not really.
opinion:
Every non-US writer I speak to hates what is happening to the genre, Australian and otherwise. 

As it stands, Australians are pressured to included identifiably US characters or settings in their stories (this is for novels, less so for shorter works). Now we and other non-US writers are excluded a second time while this narcissistic cage fight between warring US tribes plays out.
sadpuppies:
I hate it. It is Toxic US domestic politics ruining the genre. 

Slates are also toxic. It is ballot-stuffing, pure and simple. Anyone who builds a slate should be banned from nominating or voting in the Hugos. 

How on Earth the thinnest sliver of conservative white male US Christians could think they represent fandom is beyond me. How on Earth middle-class Liberal Americans fighting for middle-class American causes think they are that much more diverse than the conservatives is also beyond me (they are more diverse, but only very slightly in the global context). 

Neither particularly represent fandom, both are spectacularly good at representing their own interests.
categories: I'm most interested in the various writing categories (novel, novelette, novella, short story). They are cliques enough involved with them. The fan-writer and so forth awards feel like cliques within cliques, and I don't have the time to try to penetrate those.

hugosff: I've only recently become aware of the details of how they're decided, because of the current controversy. If you ask the questions above a year from now, my answers will be 'yes' instead of 'no', because I had no idea I, as an ordinary fan, could participate in the process. Given what I now know, I would say not, because they are nominated and voted upon by a subset of fans who may, or may not, be representative of fans as a whole. I also agree with one commentator who has pointed out that the literary categories do not represent the huge shift in speculative fiction over the past 30 years from the short form dominating the genre to novels, and series of novels, being the main stories. It would be good to see that reflected, perhaps by introduction of an additional category for series. And then, speculative fiction has exploded into mainstream acceptance in my lifetime and the sheer volume and variety of what is out there means no single award can possibly represent everything, any more than the Pulitzer or Booker prizes represent the whole of fiction.
hugofandom: I think it unlikely, for the reasons given above. There are just so many more people reading and watching speculative fiction these  days. It's no longer something you hide, embarrassed to be reading those 'silly' books. When I started reading in the genre it was still seen as pulp fiction.  Now it's mainstream and popular with all segments of society, even the literary snobs.
opinion: I have no idea, I'm afraid. I don't really discuss my reading with people, and I'm not hugely social in general. The next time I'm likely to see people with whom I could even mention the Hugos and feel like they might be aware of them is November. All of this kerfuffle will be dying away by then.
sadpuppies: I think it is very sad. On the positive side, it has made me aware that *I* can participate in deciding the awards. However, it seems to me, in general, to be a bad thing. Those who are awarded a Hugo this year won't be able to take an unalloyed pleasure in it because it is tainted by the enormously vitriolic war of words going on. The Puppies of both flavours are no more representative of fans as a whole than any one group of people can be. It also appears, from what I have been reading (at sometimes interminable length), that their agenda is self-serving--in the case of the Rabid Puppies, egregiously so, based on the content of their slate. I don't see the Puppies' opponents as representative of all fans either, although some of those are coming out with thoughtful, nuanced commentaries that help to elucidate the whole mess. On the whole, I find myself out of sympathy with the Puppies as their argument seems very much that they are having to share an award they see as 'theirs' with other people who are not them and their friends. Their contention, for example, that speculative fiction is becoming politicised and that it wasn't before makes me wonder which alternative universe  they've been inhabiting. The best SF, from writers they seem to revere, was always political.  The genre has always been used to enable discussion of political issues, as evidenced by writing from the McCarthy era. The whole thing can be summed up by one comment I saw that 'what we're seeing here is a paradigm shift'.  Those are always difficult as established interests are replaced by a new order and those who are having to share their power or privilege fight back against it.
categories: The literary categories for me.  I'm a compulsive reader, now well into middle age, and pages full of words are very much my thing.  I never really connected with comics and graphic novels came along after my tastes were set.  I still associate them very much with children's entertainment, however well I know intellectually that they are not.  For some reason I don't really connect well with film and TV representations either, despite growing up with Star Trek, Dr Who and Star Wars.
relevant: My awareness of awards beyond the Hugos and Nebula is non-existent, so I'm unable to comment here.
thoughts: Now that I know I, as an ordinary reader, can contribute to these awards, I'm going to be doing so. That's exciting.  Given the backlash against the way the Puppies have gamed the system this year, squeezing out people who may have been eminently award-worthy but do not fit their definition of speculative fiction, I suspect the way nominations are made will be the primary topic of conversation at Worldcon. Whether changes will be implemented to outlaw slates in future, I don't know, but if they are, determined individuals will find a way round it.  The thing that makes me most sad, though, is that many people's first knowledge of the Hugos will be coloured by the fight currently going on.  It tarnishes what I have always seen as a prestigious recognition of merit and people will always wonder in future about the agenda behind any given nomination or award.  It's particularly hard for writers nominated via one of the Puppy slates because something that should have been a matter for celebration has instead become a cause for soul searching and some difficult decisions.

hear:
I've always known about them.  

I'm 45 and I've read a lot (really a lot) of SF & F since the late 70s, but have always been put off a bit by organised fandom as it's a bit cliquish.
explain1:
The voting audience seems skewed toward American works.  Authors who sell well in the US get lots of votes, this relates to having US publishers actively pushing their work to US booksellers.  Britains, Australians, etc, do far less well unless they have strong US publishers and sell very well in the US.

It's not "just" a US award.  But there's definitely a strong bias there.
hugosff:
This year?  No.

Most years?  Kind of.  Some ideas old, some ideas new, some ideas borrowed, some ideas blue.  Some of it's good, some of it's crap.
hugofandom:
The Hugo award voters seem older (and because of that, more conservative) than fandom as a whole.  But SF has conquered the world: just like we are all "gamers" now, we are all "SF fans" too.

Historically the Hugos have had a bit of the wierd knee-jerk libertarianism that hard-core US SF fans have also had:  I cannot see any other reason why crap work like Niven and Pournelle's "Fallen Angels" got nominations except that they were about plucky US libertarian SF fans fighting the evil environmentalists.

(Niven and Pournelle also wrote great stuff, but that wasn't)
opinion: No idea.
sadpuppies:
The two times I did attend a big US SF con (in the late 90s) I found the very conservative US fans quite cliquish.  

Saying something that was critical of a libertarian viewpoint at a US SF con panel discussion very much got me dumped on. So much so that I never went back to another con.  It seemed obvious that all the cool kids in fandom were libertarian and outsider geeks like me were not supposed to offer other views.

Given my experience I find the SP/RP complaints about how ostracised one is for being a (shock!) libertarian as a SF con is very, very, very strange.
categories:
Novel and Novella, obviously.  Like everyone else.

I'm sometimes interested by the "Related Works", though they are sometimes about US-based SF fandom (which I find boring) rather than SF (which I love).
relevant:
They've all got good and bad points.  

Despite the criticisms I gave above, the Hugos are worthwhile.  Imperfect, like all things in this subluminary sphere, but I'll usually at least pick up the year's Hugo winner novel and read the blurb - and usually buy it.  I'll often check out the nominees.
thoughts:
The SP/RP thing is a storm in a teacup.  15 years from now only geeks like you and me will remember this fight.

In hindsight, the banning of "The Martian" as ineligible will be part of a much bigger deal.  And the story of Wright's that suffered the same fate.  These are the true signs of big problems to come for the Hugos.

That's because self-publishing is going to become more common, and for self-published works from new authors it's usual for works to start with small sales and very slowly ramp us (as opposed to when a publisher pushes your works).  That means that by the time they're popular enough to win a Hugo, they'll be more than a year old.  This game is (inadvertantly) rigged against self-published works and in favor of publishers, and in the long run that's going to matter far more for the Hugo than canine sadness.

hear: I'd been vaguely aware of them for years via media coverage and book jackets. I've only come to know how they are decided, administrated etc. in the last few years when I became a published author; as a result of that I became aware of/ part of 'fandom'. (To be clear, I had been reading sf/f for decades, but with no awareness of 'fandom', 'geek culture', conventions etc; like most readers I was just a person who bought and read books, without being part of any particular social niche associated with them.)
explain1: The vast majority of voters are American, and as a result books not published/ promoted in America during the eligibility period, or not catering to American tastes, have no chance of being nominated, let alone winning (by 'catering to American tastes' I don't mean they must necessarily be set there or have American protagonists). The Hugos might technically be a global award, but that really is just a technicality.
hugosff: No. I think sf/f is far broader in scope and ambition than is reflected in the Hugo nominations, even if the Sad/Rabid Puppies slates of the past two years were eliminated from consideration.
hugofandom: It depends on what you mean by 'fandom.' If you're talking about the con-going, niche social/cultural groupings who self-define as fandom, then I'd say the Hugo voters are a particularly US-centric subset of that. If you mean the far broader swathe of regular and passionate readers of speculative fiction who think of themselves as fans, but have mostly never heard of 'fandom', then no.
opinion: Absolutely (and this is less about geographic than demographic area). Friends and I have shared, recommended and discussed sf/f books among ourselves for years - we were 'fans' as described above - but it was only when I became an author that any of us discovered the existence of conventions and 'fandom'. The tales I bring back to them from that world make their eyes boggle.
sadpuppies:
1. The current fiasco has highlighted both how important the Hugos are to the SP/RP cabal, and how insular the Hugos' eligibility and voting procedures are; they're essentially disconnected from the broad sf/f readership. In the process the fiasco has just confirmed their irrelevance to that readership. More than that: because the SP/RP actions have spilled over into mainstream media, that broader readership is now being alerted to the fundamental untrustworthiness of the Hugo brand.
2. I think slate-based voting is dishonourable, no matter who does it.
3. The SP/RP proponents and opponents represent opposing factions of self-defined niche 'fandom'; neither of them have much to do with the majority of sf/f readers. (Having said that, I am firmly of the belief that those readers would largely find the politics of the SP/RP outdated and repugnant.)
categories: I'm primarily a reader of novels, so before I knew how the Hugos actually operated, 'Winner of' or 'Shortlisted for' on a book jacket would suggest that it was likely to be a good book. I'm not sure I knew that there were Hugos for other things, and it wouldn't have mattered anyway. Being more familiar with the process has now removed any positive association I might once have made between the Hugos and quality.
relevant: Jury-based awards like the Clarke and the Kitschies seem to me far more likely to be free from bias, and to recognise quality as opposed to popularity or hype.

hear: That's difficult to remember, but I think I first learnt about them in fandom.
explain1: I answered "no" because I think it is primarily an Anglo award, not an American award. It is telling, of course, that "Are non-American works eligible?" is included in the Hugo FAQ on Sasquan's website - I sincerely hope that it isn't, in fact, a frequently asked question, but perhaps it is.  In any case, the Anglosphere pretty much owns the Hugos as I see it, which means that my culture and world are not included. I don't see that as a problem, I'm not used to reading any kind of fiction that is actually aware of my culture and it doesn't bother me, though perhaps it should.
hugosff:
Terribly difficult question. Mostly, yes, but I think that's because I am not really aware of the non-Anglo works to the extent that I would like to be. Looking at the question from a broader perspective, no, it really doesn't reflect sf/f, because I know that there are a lot of works being written in languages I don't read, and by authors who are not promoted in the places where I see them. So I guess I would like the awards to reflect a much broader spectrum of sf/f, including the parts of it that I don't usually see.

If the question is "Should the Hugos be more about fun space operas/swashbuckling in an age where men are men and women are women and there's none of this boring preachy content about diversity", then, no, no they shouldn't. The best works of science fiction and fantasy are those that present new ways of thinking, and challenge our preconceptions. If this is done in an entertaining way, so much the better, but I think that's usually the case with the best writers. And I frankly find many of the "classics" by Heinlein et al to be pretty boring.
hugofandom: No, I don't. The Hugo Award voters are the members of Worldcon, and that's a tiny subset of fandom, mainly consisting of people from one single country (no points for guessing which one).  I know that American culture is not uniform, but it is foreign and different from other cultures all the same, and American fandom is different from other fandoms.
opinion: I think some people perhaps do, and some people probably don't. I don't think there is any kind of uniformity in this regard.  Since I live in a non-English speaking country, I imagine that there is a difference between people who are comfortable reading in English and those who are not. (Many Swedes have a reasonably good grasp of English, but most of us are very far from being bilingual, and many Swedes don't really enjoy reading in English. I think sf fans are probably more likely to read in English than the average Swede, though.)
sadpuppies:
The Sad/Rabid puppies don't represent any part of fandom that I am familiar with. That doesn't mean that there's no part of fandom that agrees with them, but fandom, as I see it, is by definition a diverse place, and so any kind of slate is counter-fannish (to coin a term) in that it represents a limitation or even negation of that diversity. That would apply to any anti-puppy slates as well, of course. 

As for the opponents, those are wildly diverse and frequently disagree with each other, sometimes quite vehemently, in all the discusions I have followed... so yes, they (we) do represent fandom, inasfar as fandom can ever be represented by anything.
categories: I don't watch a lot of films and TV series, and almost none of it is sf/f - I simply don't enjoy that medium as much as I do written text. Hence I usually haven't seen any of the movies or TV series that are nominated so I don't vote for them, and I never nominate for those categories, either.
relevant: I'm usually a little more interested in the Clarke Award and BSFA Award winners than in the Hugo winners, though there's not that much of a difference between them. I don't know much about other awards, though I've been thinking that I should look into that a bit more, now that the Hugos are broken this year, and maybe next year as well.
thoughts: This survey is an excellent idea, but of course it will only get the opinions and thoughts of people who are sufficiently familiar with English to respond to an English-language survey. It will reach the Anglosphere and a certain proportion of the people outside it - which is a lot better than only surveying US fans, of course. But when you present the results you need to keep that in mind.

sadpuppies:
While the Sad Puppies in particular probably mean to do a good thing by expanding the voter base, the method they are using (slate voting) leads to those new-comers having an unproportianally heavy influence on the ballot. So while they may aim to engage a _slightly_ under-represented group (fans of military sf, Baen, Analog, etc) they actually make the same group _heavily_ over-represented. If slate-voting doesn't stop I think that the prestige of the Hugos will vanish completely within a few years and they will be regarded as the result of political campaigning rather than aesthetic judgement.

The Sad Puppies represent a small, elitist clique of fandom, which is using slate voting to push their agenda.

The Rabid Puppies represent nothing but fascism.

hear: Long time SF fan -- don't remember ever not knowing about same.
explain1:
Just as the "World" SF Con is primarily an American convention, regardless of the nay-sayers input, the functions including Hugo Awards tend to favour American-centric positions.

This is even more emphasised when it is factored in that American insists on having a NasFIC when the "WorldCon" goes outside the U. S. A. (oh, horrors!).

I have no objection to an American "National" convention -- I doubt anyone really does object.  However, only hosting it when the U. S. A. loses a WorldCon bid smacks of whining.  Like the British National Convention (commonly called EasterCon), having an American one would be just fine, but it needs to be done every year, not only in years when the WorldCon is elsewhere.

The result of this whole situation is that the WorldCon is frankly "hijacked" by the Americans, and this is reflected in things like the Hugo Awards even when the WorldCon is outside the U. S. A.

Because, yes, they think the Hugos are about WASP Americans. In a sense, they're right (unfortunately). And they don't want to lose space to POC, QUILTBAGs, non-USAns, etc. It's quite predictable, actually.
