opinion: I think a lot of my female friends are outraged that a certain vocal few men (especially white men) are putting up a huge fuss, now that the tables are turned - now that they are a perceived minority, they don't like being excluded. On the other hand, some of my male and female friends both are concerned that now we're celebrating sf/f material from minorities, based exclusively on their race/gender/whatever and possibly ignoring merit.
sadpuppies: Slate-based voting is designed to exclude some writers of real quality. It forces slate-based winners into forever questioning whether they won by their own merit or because of politics - meaning it's a bit of a hollow victory. And instead of allowing sf/f to explore different cultures and worlds and to celebrate *difference* - which is the heart and soul of sf/f - it has shown us that, not only do we *hate* difference, but we will strike back when we're forced to change for the well-being of someone else. Do they represent fandom as I see it? In a way, yes; SP/RP are a vocal minority, and they have the backing from a vocal minority in the fandom; there are a vocal minotority who also have the backing of a vocal minority in the fandom; and in the vast middle, there are the rest of us just wishing we could move on and read some good sf/f.

It's actually turned me off a lot of sf cons, especially knowing how many people do support SP/RP and why (genuinely bigoted beliefs).  Because I do know there is a percentage of fans and professionals who *do* believe white men are the only qualified creators of sf/f, I believe SP/RP is only a symptom, not the disease itself.

hear: I've been aware of them for as long as I can remember - probably the first time I "saw" them was splattered over the cover of a book that had won, and I've taken (brief) note of them ever since.
explain1:
The Hugos are associated with Worldcon. Let's face it, Worldcon is mostly held in America - which means that, by geography, most attendants and voters will be Americans. I've always got the feeling that the occasional location outside the US is a sop to the name. "We call it Worldcon, so we've got to acknowledge their presence occasionally". But it's very clear where Worldcon's home is - and where the Hugo home is. You can't tell me that an excellent Indian novel, for instance, has the same chance as an average American one, because I simply don't believe it. 

And other countries have their own awards. The BSFA, the Vogels, the Ditmars... does the US even have an award of their own or is it the Hugo by default?
hugosff: Eh. Not really - it's not nearly as wide-ranging or imaginative as it thinks it is. Still very focused on Anglo work - UK and US especially.
hugofandom: I don't know. I've never been able to go to Worldcon (too far, too expensive) so I've never seen the voter herd in the flesh, if you get my drift.
opinion: I haven't talked to a lot of people about this, but the majority seem to roll their eyes. There's a sort of unsurprised disgust. I know that SFWA isn't the same as Worldcon, but there seem to be the same arguments, the same players, the same weird-arse political backdrop. The same expectation that I give the tiniest shit either way about Mike Resnick.
sadpuppies:
How do I view it - it's a very American bunfight, politicised along American lines. I don't know any other developed country that's so rabid in its politics, and of course what's labelled as ultra left-wing, SJW work there is often the centrist position in other countries. The SP do seem very aligned with the worst of right-wing Republicanism - or at least how they present themselves to outsiders. Have no time for them. 

The controversy doesn't really have much context in a NZ or even Australasian environment. I can't see such dichotomies ever gaining that amount of traction here. 

The whole thing just makes me feel even more... disenfranchised, if that's the word, from Worldcon. I've never been a member and frankly, this puts me off wanting to be one.
categories: Novels and novellas. The first because I read them, the second because I write them.
relevant:
NZ and Australian awards, because they're local and tend to reward local stories. 

Non-genre awards, because they often reward speculative fiction that's more literary than specifically genre awards.

hear: Vaguely heard of them from American World-con goers I am friends with, then got to know about it in more detail at Loncon.
explain1: By 'yes', I don't mean that it should be primarily American, but I suspect it's dominated by American nominators and voters. This may be partly because it is an English-language award and partly because Worldcon, despite its name, is biased towards American. I don't mean to imply that American authors are necessarily favored, but you probably have to come to the attention of the American voting base to be nominated. I daresay this is affecting southern hemisphere authors, etc, even more than British/Irish ones.
hugosff:
It's a diverse area in terms of types of literature, but an award should tend to reflect the best of the field rather than what's typical. There's a lot of stuff in sf/f that we read to pass the time, which I wouldn't consider award worthy. In other words, I do think the Hugos have been biased towards exceptional quality or entertainment value, as they should be. 

In terms of areas of interest (social diversity, military sf, to take some examples) I think the number of categories is too small and too centered around form rather than content to do justice to all those areas year after year. I feel the allocation of the awards haven't been particularly influenced by such factors in the past.
hugofandom: I think it takes a particularly dedicated kind of fan to stay current with enough of what happened in a give year to feel comfortable nominating in all those categories. Most of the books I read in a given year were published much earlier. Also I only have a pronounced interest in certain forms.
opinion: I've heard a similar opinion expressed from time to time, though it's rather drowned in the current controversy and the desire people feel to become active on one political side or another.
sadpuppies:
Yes, it was slate-based voting. It set out to be slate-based, it admits it was slate-based, it was effective in a way only slate-based voting could be.

In answer to the second question, I think I expressed myself better in the comment box at the end, so I deleted what I first wrote.
categories: I prefer the novel form and its the only category in which I'm really likely to feel qualified to nominate. That doesn't mean I want other categories ruined for people who are interested in them, of course.
relevant: Well, the Nebulas had a better list of books this year.
thoughts:
I'm not really an award focused person. Awards do tend to find 'good' books but I'm under no illusions that they find the best books or all the good books. Sure, authors feel honored when they get them, but (in selfish terms), what's that to the rest of us? What do awards do?

Well, they tend to create a common reading list after the fact, so that all of fandom is now united in being, at the very least, aware of Ancillary Justice. Everyone has an opinion on it and it creates the possibility of common conversations (or arguments). Maybe awards serve an important role in binding fandom together?

But then, they also serve to define the boundaries of fandom. People who are not interested in having those conversations (or arguments) will remove themselves from fandom or form break away groups. Some people aren't interested in seeing how many gender identities we can invent and other think that if all we can do with spaceship technology is attack alien races, let's not have them. That's the situation I think we're now in. 

'We' - fandom till now present at Worldcon - will likely no longer assent to be part of the same group. It's a shame if 'we' can't nevertheless consent to share a common space, and that's happening because groups have formed who are willing to show hostility to each other. 

In my perception, the SP group have interpreted lack of universal recognition and special status as hostility, and responded by showing actual hostility to those who were merely disinterested in them. The RP group are unashamedly hostile to a great many people. 

Both groups, incidentally, epitomize the American-ness of Worlcon/Hugo fandom. Several of Vox Day's public pronouncements constitute illegal hate speech in much of Europe which does not have the same free speech laws as the US. Larry Correia's pro-gun involvements are less heinous but also can't legally exist in Europe. A lot of the background context for the battles they've created around this year's Worldcon are only really topical for Americans.

hear:
growing up reading sci-fi novels I knew of the Hugo awards.

I think the first time I selected a book based on winning a Hugo was one of Bujold's (and it was a very good choice and an introduction to a very good author).
 
I only found out that I could actually vote on the Hugo awards due to the Sad Puppies campaign because they explained the supporting membership process.
explain1: The dominant English culture in North America (likely the world but I don't travel enough to know for sure) is American.  So it is a fact of life that awards given for English cultural works will be dominated by American tastes/fans.
hugosff:
Assuming "as I see it" means my personal opinion

Having read all the nominations for the 2013 year, in general no.  There were many stories with flat characterization and minimal plotting serving only to setup a "hook" ending or remind me of a previous story/stories that had done a similar concept better.  There were a handful of stories that stood out to me as much better.

Over my reading lifetime, I feel the Hugo awards, in general, have drifted away from stories I like and will reread to stories I find boring or depressing and will not reread.  There are exceptions of course.

Assuming "as I see it" means my view of everyone's opinion of the works

Having read all the nominations for the 2013 year, in general yes.  I can see how someone (not the same someone for each story) would like almost all of the stories and can see how they are considered worthy of an award.  Not necessarily a sf/f award mind you - since a few of the stories had only the smallest connection to a concept related to sf/f.

I have not followed how prior years works have been received by fandom in general to have an informed opinion.  I will suggest that statistically any publishing house having a sustained different portion of recent Hugo nominations in certain categories compared to their market share in the sf/f field is primary evidence to suggest a disconnect between the nominated works and the entire field of sf/f.
hugofandom:
When I think of sf/f fandom, I think of the large conventions that get news coverage - mainly to look/laugh at the nerds.  I do not attend conventions, so others may think of smaller local conventions that are less "young" (not correct word, I can't think of a better way to describe the concept).
  
I do not believe the Hugo award voters in the recent past reflect that larger fandom or tie-in novels would be nominated and likely win the awards.  The small number of actual Hugo award voters would be proof in my mind.

I believe the publicity generated by recent campaigns may help bring more voters into the Hugo award process which is only a good thing.
opinion:
First, why should I care?  My opinion is my own - do you think I should have external validation?

Second, this is my opinion at this point in time.  It may, and likely will, change in the future as my experiences/knowledge accumulate.  I expect that of others as well so my friends that may have shared my opinion in the past could have changed their minds and vice versa.

Thirdly, I expect very few people care at all about the Hugo awards meaning there is a limited number of people in my area that would have an opinion.  And I have no idea what those few people's opinion is.
sadpuppies:
A. I believe Sad Puppies 1 and 2 demonstrated that the Hugo process was fairly followed based on the number of people involved.  It also demonstrated that a vocal (hopefully small) portion of the small number of people voting/nominating were not open to new external people joining the Hugo nominating/voting process.

B. I am ashamed of the histrionics of the vocal (again hopefully small) portion of the Hugo awards that demanded the presenter resign because he may tell a joke that may offend people.  This was censorship at it's worst since it is based on a possibility not an actuality.

C. Promotion of works eligible for the Hugo award have existed for a long time, likely as long as the awards have.  I see no difference between individual work promotion and a recommended reading list and a slate to garner attention to particular works.  A vote is a vote is a vote and to think otherwise is a move away from democratic principles.  

D. Assuming Larry C, Brad T speak for Sad Puppies and Teresa NH and Patrick NH speak for the anti-Sad Puppies and ignoring the vocal minority supporting each side as best as I can.  I see one side consistently saying here are works I liked, read the works and vote for the ones you like.  I see the other side saying the Hugo awards this year need an asterisk indicating the wrong stories have been nominated at best, or declaring no award without reading the works at worst.  And in the prior year saying see told you that your stories were not good enough for an award.  One side seems more like a baby saying "nyah-nyah I was right" last year and taking their ball and going home this year, which is not a behaviour I encourage in anyone assumed to be an adult.  

E. I expect the vast majority of fandom doesn't give a hoot about the Hugo awards or this controversy.

F. I expect the majority of the minority of fandom that knows about the Hugo awards controversy would vote a pox on both their houses if that's what it takes to get everyone to just shut up about it so they could get back to talking/doing things that interest them (such as tricks to making a good costume).

G. The small minority of fandom that is involved in Sad Puppies or the opposition to it have hardened their positions and appear not to be willing to converse/accomodate/compromise with the other side.

H. My personal bias is to involving more people in the Hugo process so I encourage both sides to sell more memberships.  Sadly, one side appears to want to change the rules to discourage/prevent more involvement so I believe that side feels they have less popular support.
categories:
Yes.
Novels and movies seem like the most important/visible category to me.

Editors and fanzine type categories seem more like industry insider awards, where only people involved in the category even know the nominations let alone the broader field to make the nominations.
relevant: As a Canadian who has American culture force-fed like it or not, I will check out and perhaps buy the Canadian Aurora award winners.  I did not know these awards existed until 5 or so years ago when an author I tangentially know of won the award.
thoughts: Sorry these answers are so long, but I will do anything to distract myself from doing taxes.

explain1: The Hugos are primarily for English-language, North American science fiction and fantasy, which makes them primarily American. Certainly not exclusively; the Hugos have recognized British, Canadian and (I believe) other English-language SF&F writers, publications, podcasts, TV shows, etc. But since most Worldcons take place in the U.S., most Hugo voters are American, and are most familiar with works available in the U.S. market.

Canadian SF&F literary fandom operates in an interesting liminal space, in that we overlap significantly with U.S. fandom without being entirely of it. I think that helps people in English Canadian fandom to recognize that subsets of fandom are not the entirety of fandom.
sadpuppies:
Fandom is a galaxy made up of clusters and nodes of smaller fandoms that overlap to a greater or lesser extent. People within fandom can be part of many communities of fans. No one group entirely represents "fandom as I see it" because fandom is too large and diverse to be so easily categorized. 

However, given that every sensible human being I know could be described as opposed to the SPs/RPs, I suppose that very broad group represents fandom as I see it reasonably well.

The SPs are part of fandom, but not a large part. I've described them as an angry, conservative rump when trying to explain this year's Hugos debacle to people outside of fandom. But as much as I abhor their behaviour, their tactics, their arguments, their choices and their endless whining... they are still part of fandom.
categories:
I really don't follow short fiction, so I don't feel particularly drawn to those categories -- I agree with Eric Flint that there are more short fiction categories in the Hugos than makes sense in today's market. I suspect that even most Hugo voters couldn't explain to anyone's satisfaction what a novelette actually is.

While I understand that many people get excited about the Dramatic Presentation categories, I find them largely irrelevant to literary SF&F, which is supposed to be the point of the Hugos.

I am always interested in the nominations for Best Novel, Best Graphic Story, Best Fan Writer and Best Related Work. I think those categories are where a lot of the real heavy lifting in terms of moving the genre forward takes place, and the nominations tend to reflect that.
relevant: More relevant? Not entirely. I think that the Nebulas are often voted on by a more informed electorate, which leads to more interesting work being recognized, from a broader pool that can include works that are less commercial and less high-profile.

I view the controversy with a mixture of bemusement and horror. All involved seem to have both good arguments and a shameful excess of passionate intensity.

How does any subgroup represent a broad readership with political views and reading tastes that span the spectrum? To adapt an old joke - two fans, three opinions.

thoughts:
Diversity of opinion is clearly the hardest diversity to tolerate. For all involved.

The SP aren't as purely motivated as they claim. But who of us are? Their core grievances (insularity of the Hugo awards, intolerance of different opinions) seem correct even if the specifics (largely coming down to behind the scene conspiracies) seem laughable. Their obvious desire to provoke by choosing to nominate authors with provocative views is a peculiar way of protesting political bias and not to my personal taste (but that's life).

The RP standard bearer is a troll.

I largely agree with much of the chorus of opposition to slate voting, but the level of vitriol and self righteousness is repulsive. Those who briefed the media so one sidedly and dishonestly should hang their heads in shame. Politics writ small. 

Three cheers to GRRM for an honest and open engagement.

Oh for more conciliators and less pugilists!

thoughts:
I am saddened by the whole controversy.  Things change, attitudes change.  The ability to accept change is part of what has made humanity successful (albeit at the expense of so much else which is an attitude that needs wider acceptance).  That a small group of stick-in-the-muds can wreck was has always seemed to me to be a rather happy affair - not that I've ever had much to do with it - is a very sad reflection on the closed nature of the closed community itself.  That people allow loud(foul)mouths to take things over to this extent is a very sad mirror to hold up to the community.  I hope this inspires some deep thinking and judicious acting that attempts to remove prejudicial actions in the future.
that this has occurred in the SF/F community, which -particularly in the case of SF - strives to look outwards, is very concerning.  There is no 'what if' and 'can we' and 'wide possibilities' in the proponents of the controversy.  It seems to be a 'back when' stance which seeks to place the romanticised past ahead of the possibilities of improvement and future.  They seem to have lost their perspective on SCIENCE fiction - past is a ground point, from there all things flow into the future.  Going back is pointless.

hear: Have always known about them. I read Locus growing up, and lots of magazines like Amazing, Isaac Asimov's, etc. so may have been there.
explain1:
I answered no, but have an opinion anyway. I am aware that the Hugos are awarded by attendees of a convention, and that convention is mostly held in the US.  But to me, it is still mostly a US convention.

Here in Australia we have our own awards - the Ditmars and the Aurealis. I expect other countries to have their own awards.  

I always think of the US having two sf/f awards. Hugos and Nebulas. (And the Locus awards.) 

Interestingly, I think of the World Fantasy awards as being more international.
hugosff:
Yes and no.

The Hugos are also mostly about the written word. Or rather, the prestige in the Hugos is for books, magazines and web presence rather than media like television or films (after all, they want the Oscars and the Emmys), thus I am only talking here about books, magazines/ezines and fandom.

Most years I find that the list of finalists reflects pretty well on what is out there. There are some misses, but mostly hits.

It also reflects (which the Sad Puppies seem to object to) that the people who write SF are less and less straight, white, US males.
hugofandom:
It's only people who go to a specific convention who vote for this award. There are a lot of sf/f fans who do not go to these cons. Many who don't even know they're on.

A lot of fans find sf/f now via film or television. They may or may not go onto books.  They go to the big commercial cons if they go at all (e.g. C2E2), they don't go to WorldCon.

I don't mind that the WorldCon people vote for the Hugos rather than, say, the fans in general. The people who go to the convention read books, in general. They watch movies and tv shows as well, but they do read. They're the ones I want to vote.
opinion: I don't know.
sadpuppies:
Lots of opinions on this. (Doesn't everyone.) In no particular order:

- It wasn't cheating, but it does leave a nasty taste in one's mouth and predispose one against SP/RP.  (As the English would say, "Just not cricket.")
- Brad Torgersen comes across as a sort loser. i.e. he lost a Hugo, feels he was robbed, and started SP as a result.
- Vox Day -- scarily creepy.
- SP/RP -- totally out of touch with modern sf/f I know and enjoy, living back in the fifties. 
- The other side - disappointing. I wanted them to behave with dignity, but not all of them have.
- There's some good sf/f coming out at the moment, but the SP/RP along with the recent controversy over cosplayers at cons has made me wonder how big the 'conservative' movement is in the field. And it's making me worry. People in our field are good to each other. I don't want that spoiled.
- I also feel extremely sorry for those people that SP/RP nominated (outside of the obvious ones). Some of these are really good and should have been on the list anyway (e.g. Sheila Gilbert and Anne Sowards on the the long-form editors list. Australia's own Andromeda Spaceways In-Flight Magazine for SemiProzine.). If they win, they won't ever get the credit they deserve.
categories:
I like the categories that are related to books.

My favorite is the Best novel, then Novella and Novelette, best editor long-form -- but I like them all. The nominees give me a good idea of what's happening in the field.
relevant:
Not more relevant, but equally relevant is the Nebula. I look on this as other writers nominating books they like.

Also the Locus awards.  They are more book-specific (which is obviously what I like), but it's never clear to me who can vote for them, so I tend to look on them as not quite 'up there'. [I know that subscribers to the magazine can vote, and I subscribe, but I don't subscribe direct through Locus and I have no idea if my votes count or are discarded as a result.]
thoughts:
I respect the Hugos. To me it is still 'the' award to win. I don't want it devalued by SP/RP.

I was surprised to find that it doesn't take many votes to get something nominated. That is, that less people nominate than vote.

I'd hate to see a massive knee-jerk reaction to 'fix' slate fixing, just for the sake of reacting. I am concerned the SP/RP fiasco has damaged the Hugos.I hope that it hasn't.  I'd hope that any solution is considered and sensible. Better, that we could all be relied on to just behave, nominate if we've bought con tickets.

I really am disappointed in some of the over-reaction from fans opposing SP/RP. It drags us all down to their level. It's kind of like having a racist, sexist, foul-mouthed grandfather who embarrasses you, but mostly you try to keep him controlled and out of the way of innocent passers-by, then the whole family starts being racist, sexist and foul-mouthed too.

For what it's worth -- I love preferential voting and think it's far preferable to first past the post.

hear: I can't remember - when I was quite young as I come from a family of sf/f readers.  Probably on the front of a book.
explain1: Until quite recently I thought the Nebula and Hugos were the same sort of award and didn't realise that the Hugos were supposed to be a 'fan' award (and the Nebulas are the writing association award, if I have understood correctly).  I think a couple of years ago I would have said yes to the Hugos being a primarily US award but obviously we did have Loncon last year.  I think I do feel that sf/f is a largely US field still as so much still only gets published in the US so the awards would naturally reflect that.
hugosff: To a large degree I think so but there will always be works missed as the field of nominations is small - in particular, I no longer subscribe to Asimov and Analog so my reading of shorter fiction has decreased dramatically (but my online reading has increased).  By having so many awards for shorter fiction but only one for novels means that I find that the shorter fiction awards are still fairly reflective and seem to cast a wider net (similarly for online fanzinesetc.), however the novel award nominations can never reflect the whole field and some years feel skewed towards one type of sf/f (but that is statistically what I would expect to happen).
hugofandom:
I have to say that when I started reading sf/f it was still a time where this was perceived to be a white male area.  I have felt over the last decade a shift towards a more open an inclusive sf/f society.  I am bemused by all the different levels and degrees of fandom though and how so many of them seem exclusionary - you aren't as proper a fan as me because ...  I assume voters are self selecting and that fans who really care about the awards would vote (with the caveat that many, like me, would not have realised how easy it was to be able to vote).  I do feel though that this year's nominations do not reflect 'fandom' specifically due to the following:
1). The RP/SP3 slates seem to have been designed specifically to FILL the nominations - I.e. Not to recommend or add to the nominations but to exclude all other works.
2). Leading on from 1, the success of the slates in excluding non-slate works makes me feel that the voters this year are not representative of the whole gamut of fandom.
3). The fact that so many nominations are for the same person and one I have never heard of seems suspicious (however, I am aware that as a UK fan there are gong to be large swathes of unknown sf/f territory so I may well be wrong on this point).
4). The fact that so many nominations were published by a tiny press owned by Theodore Beale/Vox Day frankly makes me sick  - it seems obvious that this small publisher has used other fans to improve his own financial dealings and has lied to them, hiding the true goal behind other ideas and manipulating people who have become involved in all good faith.  I will also note that, having read a small amount of Vox Day's writings online I am ashamed that the outside world might associate me, a sf/f fan, with him and his views.

I would also note that I feel very sorry for the nominated people this year as they will have been tainted by the controversery and what should be one of the highlights of their careers cannot be the happy event it should be.
opinion: Those I have discussed this with, yes.
sadpuppies:
I have actually spoken at length about this in an earlier section.  I find it hard to trust even the more reasonable amongst the SP/RP due to the exclusionary nature of their slate (pushing all other works out as the expressed goal) and also due to the name-calling and use of acronyms blatantly designed to insult the other side (SHW, Chorts etc.).  I do think that the SP/RP 'side' has suffered from association with Vox Day and also because the SP rationale seems to have changed over the years.  I am also more naturally drawn to the opponents side but have been horrified by some of the attacks made and would not want my name associated with the extremists on either side.

I do think that a positive side effect of this will have been to make more fans, like myself, aware we could nominate and vote in Hugos and I feel that next year will be self-correcting and this year is a sad blip in the sf/f world.

I think that the arguments have also drawn out a very wide range of fans and have hopefully widened participation.  Although, I would like the very narrow SP/RP arguments to die down quickly and the discussion to turn to sharing sf/f we all love and how a wider group of fans can become more engaged.

Finally, I always thought that sf in particular was about breaking barriers and hope and the future and I have been saddened by the SP/RP situation as the group seem to be gong expressly against that element of sf which I love (one example is the cereal analogy).
categories: As I mentioned above, I am currently reading a lot less short fiction so the to shows/films, online categories and novel are the ones currently more relevant to me.  However, I have previously subscribed to various periodicals and will probably do so again.  I also think that the sf/f is unique in its awarding and recognition of shorter fiction and that this allows us to 'grow' amazing authors in a way that other fields don't.  I find that the first novels published by sf/f authors seem of significantly higher quality than those in other genres I read.  (Please note that I am not implying that shorter fiction is easier or less worthy than novels - there are novelists who are rubbish at writing short stories/novellas/novelettes as they do require different skills.  But the time investment in shorter fiction is, well, shorter, allowing authors to hone their skills as they go through the story telling cycle more times, more quickly).
relevant: Before this controversery, I would have ranked Hugos, Nebulas and World Fantasy Awards roughly equally.  I would use any award, even the smaller ones or awards I haven't heard of, as a signifier of quality, that the story was interesting but I wouldn't automatically buy anything just because it won an award - I would ask friends or read a sample first but an award can help bring something to my attention (like an author quote on a cover or a recommendation from a trusted blog or a friend).
thoughts: I will be getting a supporting membership for next year's WorldCon and nominating and voting.  I am also saving up to attend a WorldCon in the next few years.  I think the whole SP/RP has made me realise that, if I want sf/f to be an opening and welcoming community I need to be more actively involved to help that happen.

sadpuppies:
I can't understand how a group, or two groups, can actively oppose increased diversity when they are supposed to be writers interested in the new and the fantastic. I think it's foolish of them to indulge in conspiracy theories and I think they are indulging in the professional victimhood they usually ascribe to their so-called enemies. I agree that the social justice movement has been guilty of online bullying of those who do not subscribe to their politics but, for the Puppies to align themselves with Gamergate, whose misbehaviour extends well beyond twitter-bullying, is utterly hypocritical. 

I think it's poor sportsmanship for them to hijack the Hugo awards and to me it speaks of sour grapes. 

I think fandom sits somewhere in the middle of this controversy, but I expect that this will drive them away from the Puppies, both Sad and Rabid. It has certainly done so for me.

Yes! I'd love to see some surveys with hard data. 

Where DOES fandom stand on these issues? 

What proportion of award winners are North America? What proportion of the publishers are from the Big 5? 

Are the Hugo voters representative of fandom in general?

What is the proportion of fandom that reads books as well as consuming SF/F in other media?

hear: Probably from buying one of Asimov's anthologies of winners in the early 1970s when I was about fourteen!
explain1: It is an award for works written in English (including in translation of course), and the majority of English speaking writers and fans are American. The awards were conceived in the US, and the majority of conventions are held in the US. There is a natural and not necessarily harmful bias in favour of the US.
hugosff: Prior to 2015, yes, broadly speaking. There is a tendency to nominate the same few people time and again, but there is nothing new about that.
hugofandom:
Again, prior to 2015 the voting population reflected those fans who were deeply committed to fandom, whether in the sense of (say) volunteering at cons, or in the sense of blogging and talking about books, films and artists.

There's been a large uptake of voting memberships this year. Some of those are obviously supporters of the Puppy slates, but quite a lot must be people like me, who saw what happened last year and how the wind was blowing this year, and decided to register. I've been reading sf for nearly fifty years, but rarely bothered to register to vote. The controversy has at least stirred me into action!
opinion: Broadly, yes. Offhand, I can't think of anyone who supports the aims of the Puppies. Most of us are horrified at the idea of a certain writer receiving six nominations - his work is neither original or interesting. Equally, most of us find the indignation of their opponents faintly amusing. This kind of slate voting was bound to happen eventually. Minor tinkering with the rules could prevent it in years to come - reduce the number of nominations in each category an individual is allowed to make.
sadpuppies:
While I can understand the feeling among the Puppies that the Hugos have fallen into the hands of a small clique who keep voting for each other - and I think the reaction on the Neilsen Hayden blog has only reinforced that impression - the introduction of a slate seems to me against the spirit of fandom. The extremists on both sides are behaving badly - the sense of entitlement, of ownership, coming from parts of the "SJW" camp is almost as nauseating as the Rabid Puppies.
  
Increasing the number of fans who vote seems to me a good thing, but I'd rather they thought for themselves than followed someone else's edict! And I suspect that after a few years only those who are truly interested in the field will continue to vote - the rest will fade away as some new cause comes to light.
categories: For me, the novel, novella, novelette and short story are the most important categories, with best pro artist fifth and best related sixth. The rest don't matter to me as much - I prefer the written word.
relevant: The Nebula, maybe, but AS relevant, not more relevant!
thoughts: At the end the contretemps all seems very American and very self-indulgent. But I despise the Puppies and their backward looking agenda. Most telling of all, the Puppies themselves can't write to save their lives. (Kratman? Wright? Torgerson? Up for Hugos? This is a joke, isn't it?)

hear: Originally from the back of the science fiction books I got from the library as a child.

categories:
Yes.

The core Hugo categories for me are the novel and 3 short fiction categories, as well as the fan orientated categories (fanwriter, fan cast, best related work). Those are the categories were the Hugo has the best chance of getting things right. 

The various media categories (dramatic presentation long & short, comics) are pointless because they don't venture beyond very mainstream tastes. 

The editorial categories are for the most part voted on by people with no clue what editors do (including myself) and therefore more an exercise in name recognition.

The fan and professional artist categories are handicapped by lack of interest and knowledge of sf/f artists and what work they've done this year.

thoughts: If the Hugos are to be less American and more diverse, there need to be more non-American Worldcons. However, we should be careful too not to make it just a toss up between European and American cons, but also get fans on other continents involved.

explain1:
It's a tired analogy, but the "World" Con is somewhat like the "World" Series in baseball, in that Americans are sure that they invented it, they are the best at it, and they deserve to win every year, so why bother holding the World Series anywhere but in the USA?

Okay, things are a little better, in that cheap global travel has allowed the fans to set up World Cons all over the world. Still, we get inordinate grumbles from US fans about how the foreign venues are too foreign for them, and a great inconvenience to travel to. Not to mention too expensive, and sometimes the foreigners win the awards, and that can't be right!

If the Sad Puppies' followers want to be represented in fandom, they should do what the rest of do, and attend cons, meet people, and not be asses (most of the time).

hugofandom: Partially, yes.  Sf/f has become very mainstream, and looking at the books awarded/nominated, they too are most often very mainstream (J.K Rowling, McMaster Bujold, Gaiman, Robert Sawyer, etc.) At the same time there are a significant number of readers who don't go within sniffing distance of any of the books on the Hugo slate but who are firmly entrenched in sf/f.

sadpuppies: Like the American political system which depends on lobbying, this year's slate is the natural result of the system. I don't like the slate, even the Leckie, but unless I disagree with the system, I must accept what the system produces.  Therefore, the question of whether SP/RP proponents/opponents represent sf/f fandom is like asking does Obama represent Americans' interests?  The answer of course must be no. He is what the system produced. So if you want to complain, complain about the system, not the result.
categories: Everything except the tv & film and artist categories.
relevant: Any juried award, e.g. The World Fantasy, the Arthur C. Clarke, the Mythopoeic, the James Tiptree Jr., for the simple reason they have a public agenda and bring in experts to judge the year according to that agenda.  Those agendas covering wide spectrum of culture, they therefore become more relevant than simple popularity.
thoughts: I hope this year's Hugo finally disillusions the world that the award is the 'genre's most prestigious'.  Any time popularity is purported to be equal to quality is a joke.  Like Britney Spears being Artist of the Year, the Hugo is the pop music award of sf/f.  It's therefore time the Hugos forgo voting and just aggregate bestseller lists.  (What better democratic representation then what people choose to spend their money on?) This would be more accurate and "representative of fandom".

hear: I read SF and Fantasy, and have bought books that have Hugo award successes listed on their cover. Now I am part of the spec fiction writing community (amateur writer) and the whole of fandom has blown up about the latest awards.
explain1: I see the awards as an indication of books popular with a US audience. Even though Worldcon has been held in other places, even Australia, it appears dominated by US fans. I have no problem with this. It makes sense, since the largest part of fandom seems to take place in the US. Therefore it seems natural to me that stories, novels and shows successful in the US are more likely to do well in the Hugos. There will be some exceptions, most likely British TV shows (Dr Who?). Australian work is unlikely to be nominated unless it came via a US publisher, just because there are too few of us Aussies and Worldcon is usually a long way away. The exception I can think of is the Encyclopaedia of Science Fiction co-authored by Australian Peter Nicholls, but published in the UK.
hugosff: They reflect a significant part of SF/F. Not all of it.
hugofandom: It reflects a significant part of SF/F fandom. Not all. Some popular books won't be nominated - I think the Hugos represents more of the hard-core of fandom, those who can afford to pay enough and spend enough time to go to Worldcon, and also the SF/F writing world. I'm not sure they represent the average reader who might be fishing through the SF/F shelves at a bookshop or the internet equivalent to find good books, and who may be content to read what the book shop offers them, rather than what the SF/F scene online is talking about.
opinion: I don't know if others in Australia share my opinion. I suspect that we would mostly agree that even our best Australian authors are a long shot for a Hugo award, not because of lack of quality, but because we don't have the US fan-base, or maybe don't move in that US writing scene. We aren't meeting US or British editors and publishers at cons; we aren't establishing those relationships over various workshops that help with this in the US scene. It's human nature to want to nominate people you have a good relationship with over those whose work may be equally good but whom you have had no dealings with.
sadpuppies: I think it's very sad. I don't think the RP represent much of fandom - I hope they don't. With SP, I think it's more complex. I think there's a genuine desire there to see old-school 'entertaining' works nominated, and the organisers seem to genuinely believe good work that does not tick the "liberals" boxes is being overlooked. I think in the sense that being part of a scene can help being nominated - being one of the "cool kids" -- they could have a point. However, I have thoroughly enjoyed some of the winning and nominated Hugo authors in the past, so I personally disagree that the more literary and liberal works that have won are not entertaining. For instance, I loved Ancillary Justice.
categories: I find novels, novellas, movies, tv shows, semi-prozines and short stories interesting and of value. I read across the spectrum; never as much as I'd like to of anything. I'd love to see more Australian work considered. (Margo Lanagan, Seahearts anyone?)
relevant: I've found the British Kitschies awards a a great reflection of my taste. How could I not enjoy a Golden or Red Tentacle award? Every one of their recommendations I've read so far has been fabulous. International - yes. Jury judged.
thoughts:
I hope the Hugos survive this. Perhaps the nomination rules need to change to avoid the slates dominating. I think it would be sad to see any group dominate, but I enjoy having an award where the committed genre fans have a say, rather than just what is popular at the book store. 

I also hope the authors/magazines nominated this year are given a fair go and judged on their merit, especially those who were excited about their nominations and didn't realise it came on a slate at first. 

Kary English's story, "Totaled" is very good and worth a read. She is a liberal and kind person - I've met her online. I hate to think of her having to put up with all this crap. Likewise, Andromeda Spaceways Inflight Magazine is a magazine that deserves more attention, whether it wins a Hugo or not. As an Australian magazine, it may not have been nominated normally. It used to be reviewed by Tangent Online, but for some unknown reason, they stopped. With that lack of coverage, the magazine's profile probably fell.  I hope some good comes out of this and that more people read them. I'd love to see more Australian works included in the Hugos, but I do see them as primarily a US fandom award.

hear: Writers' commentary in the paperback SF I read when I was growing up.
explain1: SF fandom (which I tend to think of as Old Fandom these days) began as an American phenomenon centred on the communities built by American magazines. Where it exists elsewhere, the culture of its origins is replicated.
hugosff: They never have, really.
hugofandom: Yes, if by "sf/f fandom" we mean the small but influential fandom that originated in American magazines and is now very much one fandom among many.
opinion: I assume so, but it's not something that comes up often in conversation with fans. Which is arguably significant in itself.
sadpuppies: Fandoms naturally tend to be conservative in a cultural sense and this is far from the first time there's been a backlash against new trends in F/SF writing, so in that sense the SP/RP fuss is representative of fandom. I'm tempted to argue that Vox Day and his mates are more interested in the wider cultural conflict than they are in fandom and thus less representative but there's no sign they're particularly important or influential anywhere outside of F/SF fandom.
categories: The written fiction categories interest me more than comics and media (which tend to suffer from a narrow view of their fields) or the fannish categories (because I'm not very interested in organised fandom).
relevant: If I'm looking for recommendations I generally find juried awards like the Clarke or the Tiptree are more reliable. I don't know if that makes them "relevant", though.
thoughts: I've had an ambivalent relation to fandoms and fan culture for a long time, and the current Hugo fuss is a minor example of why that is.

hugosff: They reflect the 10% of Sturgeon's Law of works marketed as speculative fiction. (Works marketed as literary fiction, romance etc are seldom considered for the Hugos.)
hugofandom: No, it reflects the makeup of the American fandom of written science fiction, some of whom also happen to like fantasy and non-written science fiction. Non-Americans appear to be a small minority among Hugo voters. People who are uninterested in written science fiction and people interested solely in fantasy don't seem to care much about the Hugos.
opinion: I don't know.
sadpuppies: The Sad Puppies acted unethically, and their leaders are clueless. The Rabid Puppies are out to destroy the Hugos, and their leader is evil. Proponents and opponents of Sad Puppies represent parts of fandom. Proponents of Rabid Puppies are enemies of fandom.
categories: No, other than my utter disinterest in the editing categories.
relevant: The Hugos are as relevant as other national speculative fiction awards. They are generally as relevant as the Nebulas, but this year the Nebulas are far more relevant. The continued existence of the Hugos is not as important as the continued existence of awards in countries where the speculative fiction scene is much smaller than in the United States.
thoughts: The Hugo awards website should stop calling the Hugo prestigious. Here is why: http://thebooksmugglers.com/2015/02/sff-in-conversation-jared-shurin-poking-at-awards-stop-trying-to-make-prestigious-happen.html

I'd need to have a lot more information to answer that, and to have read much more widely. SFF is so huge that I'm not sure anything could reflect it without being SFF itself. But I notice that Wind Up Girl won, and that definitely is not my kind of SFF, no.

SFF contains multitudes. A single award could never encompass it all.
hugofandom: I think they are probably at the core of fandom, which is again a multitude of people enjoying SFF in various ways. But a lot of people I know online who are part of the Hugo fandom are people who are passionate about SFF, in book and other forms.
opinion: I suspect most people in Britain don't know about and don't care about the Hugos. Although if you mention Dr Who their ears might prick up.
sadpuppies: I think this whole fight for the soul of SFF, if you like, is very much an American thing. Of course we have sexism and racism in the publishing industry here, but I don't think it's a cause in which people are actively engaged. That said, I have felt and shown more interest in the Hugos this year than any other year, simply because people about whom I care care about it. People I know have been adversely affected, not just by the rigged nominations but why the spillover into online life, and by the involvement of GamgerGate. I like to think the SP/RPs are acting of desperation because diverse SFF is a rollercoaster that cannot be stopped. But again it's a very small part of fandom that is just amazingly loud.

hear: Through science fiction fandom years ago.
explain1: It's mostly Americans who are Worldcon members because Worldcon tends to be held in the US. It also tends to be held in the US over an American holiday weekend, Labour Day, which isn't a holiday elsewhere. To vote for the Hugos, you must be a Worldcon member. It's expensive to just be a supporting member -- not attend and be able to vote. However, when you live outside of North America, it's expensive to attend Worldcon, unless it's anywhere near you. For example, I live in the UK, so I've been to Worldcon twice this century -- this past year in London and a few years back in Glasgow. If I lived in the US, I could attend it more. Yes, I know that the opposite is true -- it's expensive for Americans to leave the US and a lot of Americans don't have passports. However, there are a lot of sf/f writers/fans outside of the US whose voices aren't heard.
hugosff: Not really, particularly not this year. I mean, I love the Dresden books, but I don't see this one book as a Hugo winner. I'm an English teacher. Hugo winners should be like the Booker Prize or the Pulitzer Prize for sf/f -- not just a popularity contest.

opinion: Yes.

I opted out of following the news about the SP thing pretty quick (I found it deeply disheartening - see below), but, from what I understand, some very entitled people thought they should have won some awards. 

They were so Squidward Tentacles about the whole thing that they decided only a great power (SJWs!) could be preventing them from achieving the recognition their genius deserved. They therefore got a bunch of people to push their books into the limelight where the (previously) fearful and silenced majority would finally be able to heap acclaim upon them. They would unleash a counter revolution, and once more that most endangered of species, the straight able-bodied white male protagonist, would have a place in western SF. The genre would thus be saved. 

At least, that's my understanding of the situation.

I think the best thing that can be said about it is that it wasn't technically against the rules, and when that's the best you've got, you're really scraping the bottom of the barrel.

These tedious assholes in no way represent me, or the bulk of my experience of fandom, for which I am exceedingly grateful. 

I think they represent a hardcore cadre of crybabies. They are exactly the sort one finds in comics fandoms too. I have no doubt there is considerable overlap.

X:
Too many thoughts to really make manageable. 

Over all? This whole situation has really distressed me. 

I'm female, I'm queer, I'm a writer, I'm in fandom. The last time I felt this down about fandom was when I was at an SF convention (the theme was post-apocalyptic worlds) where talk about rape and women getting "back into their natural roles" was super normalized, a given underlying all the panel discussions. That was 2013.

I am so accustomed to feeling like I am human with full rights that when people who view me as a lesser creature surface, I am startled and depressed by it. The politics of the sad puppies are clear and they're vile. People like Vox Day would like to see me 'fixed' or dead.   

Considering those things, I would frankly rather see the end of the Hugos than see them become a soapbox for people who would not treat me as an equal human. I wish the response to the slate had been stronger and more active. There was a great deal of outrage but not a lot of action. A lot of people declared support, I saw a lot of blog posts about how important diversity is, and that's great, but the fact remains that whatever the outcome, the Puppies got a very big soap box for a while and I'm not convinced they can't just grab it whenever they like.

I'm sorry, I know that's terribly depressing.

hear: I guess through Twitter?  I write, so I follow a lot of writers/bookish folks.  May have read about the Hugos in a writing magazine.  Had probably heard about them in passing years ago, but so passingly that I don't remember.
explain1: Honestly I didn't know the Hugos were American until this year, when I gained some (vague) understanding of what the voting situation/process is.  As a Canadian, I don't feel that far removed from the USA, so it's hard to tell whether other countries (say, anywhere in Europe) care about the Hugos.
hugosff:
Hard to answer "yes" given all the recent controversy - and I think this is a complicated question.  

Do the works reflect sf/f as I "see" it?  Like, on the shelf?  Mainstream?  Sure.  Minorities of all kinds are underepresented, and there's generally controversy about it.  Seems about right.

Do the works reflect sf/f as far as what I, personally, see when I look for something to read?  When the authors and artists I follow share news about their content?  What I seek out?  The works that I think deserve attention and discussion?  Not really, but I'm one reader and I'm *trying* to read more diverse works.

Just like anything that's a popularity contest, there's more to the nominations than statistics.
hugofandom: Yes - a fandom that is at least partly organized, very divided and weirdly political.
opinion: I live in a very diverse city - Vancouver, Canada.  I am sure that others in my area share my opinions, though I don't know a lot of locals who talk books.  My book friends are mostly online and we're all pretty disappointed over the Hugo shenanigans - but I generally make friends with people whose opinions I can respect, so it's no surprise that we all agree.
sadpuppies:
I think my opinion of the controversy is probably pretty clear already, but if not: I shake my head.  As a girl who grew up reading sf/f, I feel that fans of something like this just SHOULDN'T be this way.  The lessons that sf/f works usually teach are about acceptance and fighting stereotypes and building new worlds and just... stuff that is generally great.  So how come we can't be great to each other?  Have we forgotten what drew us to these works in the first place?  Are we so desperate to prove ourselves that we need to quash the voices of others?  Frankly, I'm disappointed and pretty pissed, but I can't say that I'm very surprised.  I'm part of a lot of fandoms, and I've seen this kind of vitriol before (I feel it's very similar to fake-nerd-girl hate - like some people's identities are so cemented to their fandom that they can't accept that someone else ALSO likes that thing - it's madness) - but it makes me sad that it's crept into books.  Books!  Have we forgotten that we're all nerds together?!

Obviously, SP/RP proponents AND opponents represent fandom as I see it.  It saddens me that this has to be a part of fandom at all.
categories: Honestly, I know more about the controversy than I know about the awards themselves.

I see it a lot like GamerGate and the comics fandom. A few people who think that they are genuinely doing good things, but the driving force behind it all is full of people who don't want to accept that the world is changing and their fiction is changing to reflect that. They're scared and feel things are being taken away, so they lash out at those perceived threats without understanding that no one's taking their stories away; there are just more stories around now for more people and those stories are now also getting recognition.
